Action films, although were used to them in abundance since the 80's, are a great form of entertainment. A good action blockbuster, injects you with so much adrenaline that by the time the end credits roll, your gasping for breath. Not something you see often these days, however films like The Raid, James Bond and Onk Bak lay testament to just how intense you can feel, watching a movie. What these films pride themselves on are wonderful choreography, well shot sequences and of course characters we give a toss about. Having a protagonist being flung around, on screen, no stunt men and caring about the outcome is a rarity these days. Much to my surprise, Edge Of Tomorrow pretty much delivers on a whole host of levels, ultimately falling short on few cliche but giving us a gasping for air experience. After what seems to be an Alien invasion on planet earth, in the not too distant future, world powers begin to create mech suits, enhancing soldiers potential on the battlefield, turning them into a form of super soldier shall we say. Major Cage, does a round of publicity to advertise and sell the war, which he strongly believes the human race will win, with this new technology. Cage soon finds out that he has in deed been duped and is framed and forced into the armies invasion of France, to help with some propaganda, the invasion should go down a treat and thus ensure that the human race stands a chance against the invasion. Only everything that can go wrong does go wrong, leaving Cage one of the few men left, paired with Rita a bad ass soldier nicknamed Full Metal Bitch, to fight the war, not with the mechs but with an entirely new and unknown way of thinking. I have essentially summed up the opening 30 minutes here and to go any further will ruin, all enjoyment and surprise. First off, the story is a lot more intricate and well placed out than it first appears, in fact when the film does shake it up, it does so using humour and some out of this world editing, to craft an experience the film really thrives on. It's also not afraid to build on these ideas somewhat and you as a viewer soon become as lost as some of the characters down to some sterling production work. The screenplay co written by Christopher MacQuarrie is decent and hilarious. It is also, underneath its complex skin, simple. It doesnt try too hard to be intelligent, it does however rely on us caring about our characters. Of course who better to fit the criteria than Tom Cruise, like him or loath him, the man is charismatic, enthusiastic and more importantly 110% involved in everything he does. That means when Doug Liman comes to film the action scenes, we are actually seeing Tom running, jumping, being battered left right and centre, constantly all in a mix of practical and CGI which works strangely to great effect. Emily Blunt plays Rita and although not the greatest female character committed to cinema, she is bad ass, with a touch of human about her. This makes for a very strong female lead and a breath of fresh air to see a woman kicking the seven shades of shit out of an alien race. The film jumps through hoops to heighten this by making Cruise the weaker one at first and having Blunt take on alien mechs with a sword. The rest of the cast sadly, minus Noah Taylor, is just kind of... Well, there! The grunts are grunts, Bredan Gleeson is paper thin and Bill Paxton puts in an admirable effort, however due to the frantic and repetitive nature the film requires, Paxton soon outstays his welcome. Luckily the lead roles are the meat of the piece and both actors hurtle their way towards the finish line all guns blazing. The action sequences themselves are pounding, shocking at first but soon becoming almost like a video game, in the extent in which it becomes so overwhelming we the audience find ourselves at the edge of our seat, never mind tomorrow. The film uses a vast array of practical effects and it pays off massively, allowing the CGI to become allowable. The wars are bold and wild, almost like a CGI littered version of Saving Private Ryan's opening moments. The film of course has some rather annoying dips, which stop this film short of being a wonder. First of all the ending loses its testicular fortitude for a more happy joy, joy ending, which just ruins any tension and sacrifice brilliantly crafted in the scenes leading up to it. The film also hurtles are such a speed that, it takes you quite some time to catch up, your not grounded very well as you start of the journey, leaving you completely disorientated, before finding your bearings. I would go as far to say an effect used to help relate to Cage but he at least has a clue about what is going on prior to the invasion. The film also dips here and there, showing promise with other arcs and not taking them, leaving you scratching your head and asking the question what if. Aside the rushed beginning, chicken shit ending and a few pot holes along the way, the movie is consistant and brilliant. It wont win any awards, although the editing team surely deserve to work in cinema for the rest of time, but it is a fast and furious action/sci fi flick, with huge amounts to offer, even a laugh here and there.

Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

I always remember the tagline, Live, Die, Repeat easier than this title.  It was always printed bigger on the posters.  Although this sci-fi actioner didn't do as well at the box office, it can sure improve on DVD and cable viewing.

Major William Cage (Tom Cruise) is an armed forces PR man, but gets thrown into active combat duty by General Brigham (Brendan Gleeson).  He is pretty much dropped into a beach-head frontal attack (basically a suicide mission) that is being demolished by an alien force that is taking over the planet.  When he is killed off, he finds that he is repeating the events over and over again in a constant time loop.  Think of the movie, Groundhog Day only with aliens.  :-)

He soon meets up with a Special Forces warrior Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt) and finds that he had killed a certain type of alien that allows him to resets the day after each death.  Knowing the future, he can use this to his advantage to try to learn from his mistakes, to train, and arrange to destroy the alpha aliens.

This is a good movie with a nice scence of humor and I highly recommend it.

Directed by Doug Liman (Swingers (1997), Go (1999), The Bourne Identity (2002) and Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005)), and adapted from the Japanese Manga novel All You Need Is Kill by Hiroshi Sakurazaka. This is a high concept action sci-fi thriller, which on the surface melds together the time loop scenarios of Groundhog Day (1993) and Source Code (2011)), but it manages to work very well. An alien invasion has taken over most of mainland Europe, these are aliens known as Mimics, and they're heading for the UK. Major William Cage (Tom Cruise), a spokesman for the United Defense Forces is signed up to fight, something he doesn't want to do, but has to after he tried to blackmail General Brigham (Brendan Gleeson), he ends up stripped off his rank and thrown into fighting the Mimics on the beach at Normandy. Cage is killed in battle, only to wake up the morning before it happened. He tries every way he can to get out of it, but he can't and the day repeats itself again and again, but he soon finds his answer into getting out of it in Sergeant Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt.) It's a very good idea for a film, and the battle sequences on display are almost insane, and it manages to have some good fun along with way without (pardon the analogy) becoming repetitive. It's not like other action films, this is that rarest of beast, an action film that's also a clever and intelligent think piece.

What a great film. Tom Cruise & Emily Blunt are brilliant in their roles as soldiers in a war against an alien race wiping out what is left of mankind.  It is a fresh idea for the science fiction genre based on the graphic novel. Live, Die and Repeat. Tom Cruise plays Major William Cage, a military officer who works in the PR department who has never been in battle. He pisses off the wrong person, and finds himself stripped of his rank, thrown into a platoon of soldiers headed for a suicide mission. Cage dies in battle only to have alien blood cover his remains. He wakes up reliving in a time loop the moment he is cast into the platoon on it's way to its suicide mission. As Cage dies repeatedly he develops skills to predict the outcome of certain moments to avoid them, he meets Rita while in battle and before she dies she says come find me when you wake up. As he goes through his time loop he finds a way to find Rita. She doesn't believe him at first until he describes what is happening to him. Rita introduces him to Dr. Carter who explains what is happening to Cage.  They strategize how to defeat the enemy...and Rita must train Cage so they can survive longer then they have in previous time lines. Tom Cruise has very funny moments poking fun at his character. Emily Blunt is dazzling as the super solider.  The movie has a fast pace, and has very funny moments as Cage's character dies in very humorous ways.  It is fun to watch, has great cinematography, and is well directed. There is a sense of fun in watching this film.

Starring: Tom Cruise, Emily Blunt, Brendan Gleeson, and Bill Paxton
Directed By: Doug Liman
Rated: PG-13

Based on the Manga, "All You Need Is Kill" by Hiroshi Sakurazaka. Humanity has finally won a battle in the war against an invading alien force known as Mimics. Now determined to retake Europe and win the war, soldiers in special weapon suits began to push back on the beaches of France. A soldier named Cage, who is unwillingly sent to the front lines, witnesses the slaughter as they walk right into an ambush. He is killed in action than awakens to find out he has restarted the day again. He is caught reliving the same day over and over until he dies in battle each time. With the help of star soldier Rita, the only one who will believe him, he must find a way to escape from this loop and stop the invaders from destroying the world.

If anyone could possibly have had a worse time then Bill Murray in Groundhog Day, it would probably be Tom Cruise as Cage in Edge of Tomorrow; seeing how the only way for him to restart the day is thru him unavoidably dying (sometimes hilariously). I got hooked on the cool concept right away and pretty much decided I was going to check it out after seeing the trailer, despite Cruise's kind of lack luster films in the last few years. I don't dislike the guy though and think he's a decent actor so I wasn't going to completely stay away because of that. While it's not as good as other films of the similar subject matter (like the above mentioned Groundhog Day or Source Code) it was still entertaining.

Tom Cruise does a nice job here. I don't really remember seeing him in a reluctant hero role before now. Cage is flat-out a coward when we first meet him and Cruise does a great job of showing that without still being completely unlikable.
Emily Blunt is his opposite as the tough as nails, gruff soldier and the two work good together and play off of each other well as she is forced to train him so he can actually stand a chance in battle.
It was also cool seeing Franz Drameh from Attack The Block show up as part of the squad of well acted supporting characters too, which included the always fun Bill Paxton.

The ending felt a little tacked on, but an opposite ending wouldn't really have worked any better. That's really my only gripe about it. The aliens were cool and pretty original looking and memorable, it's very well acted, and it has some great scenes as Cage tries multiple times to make it thru the battle on the beach alive.
I enjoyed the movie. Time travel/time loops are a favorite subject of mine. It did a good job of not taking itself too serious and throwing in some funny moments to go along with the serious ones. It doesn't really stand far out from a lot of other movies and will probably be forgotten in a few years (much like Cruise's Oblivion), but I think it's still worth seeing if you are looking for something new to see and won't leave disappointed. I passed on the 3D showing so I don't know if that was worth while, but the 2D show is worth checking out for a matinee.

The plot is one that has been done before but not on such a grand scale. Set in a futuristic world the Earth is at War. Major William Cage played by Tom Cruise (Mission Impossible, Vanilla Sky) is a military journalist never seen a day of combat in his life. After refusing to be front and centre and report from the impending battle against an alien race known as "Mimics", Cage is arrested and knocked out, when he wakes he finds himself in cuffs, his rank has been revoked and now finds himself labelled as a deserter. Cage finds out that now instead of being a reporter on the mission he will now be a soldier, a suicide mission as it becomes apparent. Major Cage dies within 5 minutes of landing after seeing a Special Forces officer Sergeant Rita Vrataski played by Emily Blunt (The Devil wears Prada, Looper) first die. Next thing he wakes up one day earlier and finds the day suddenly repeating Cage seems to be caught in some kind of time loop every time he dies the day starts over... There is a lot to give away to the plot if I go any further into the story so I'll leave it there.
This is one of those films that we could discuss for years and never come to a solution; I'm sure everyone who sees it will come to their own conclusion which makes it well worth seeing in my opinion. As I stated earlier though I'm a sci-fi geek that needs things to at least work even in made up lands. There is so much that doesn't make sense when thought about, but then there is enough goodness to forgive those mistakes as well.
Cruise is actually pretty good in his role not that it's too much of a stretch from other characters he has played before. Blunt does just as well in her kick ass bitch role as well. The majority of this film was shot on green screen which isn't a problem it just means judging its artistic creativeness with cinematography is almost pointless. The CGI of the Mimics I loved though I thought they were great.
Not really one for the kids but to be honest I don't believe they would understand its storyline anyway.

If Saving Private Ryan, Groundhog Day, and Starship Troopers all got mashed into one movie, Edge of Tomorrow would be that movie. This movie is about a desk military officer played by Tom Cruise who is operating during a massive alien invasion in Europe that is about to spread to the entire world in the future. The world's military forces combine to launch a massive invasion on the alien forces, and Tom Cruise's character is forced into the battle. When he's quickly killed however, he awakes at the beginning of that day and is trained by a powerful soldier played by Emily Blunt to be a warrior and while reliving the same brutal combat over and over again, the two become closer to victory. This movie had epic intense battle scenes that were basically the WWII D-Day invasion with robots and aliens. This movie was exciting, thrilling, and each time Tom Cruise awoke and restarted the battle, it was different each time. It didn't get old. This is one of my favorite movies of the year and I highly recommend checking it out.

All You Need Is Kill, Edge of Tomorrow, Live Die Repeat, I really don't care what you call it, bottom line, this movie was absolutely incredible. It's probably one of the most original plots I've ever read, seen, or experienced in any medium and Hiroshi Sakurazaka is genius for coming up with such an incredible story. Even with a great story, movies have been known in the past to not succeed in delivering on the fantastic plot. Luckily, Doug Liman executed the story arc to perfection and Tom Cruise and the stunning Emily Blunt were flawless. These two essentially carry the entire film and display great chemistry in the process. The action sequences are done well and the cinematography is excellent. Honestly, there's not a single flaw in the film, no matter how hard I try to find one. Yes, it is science fiction, not only from an alien perspective but also because the entire film is based on the concept of a time looping paradox,  so there is an element of suspended disbelief that is required in order to enjoy the film. That being said, I think this movie did as good a job as any I can recall at staying true to the concept. Overall, this might have been the best film of 2014. Unfortunately the marketing team failed miserably at giving it the exposure it deserved. Additionally, the ending may have confused some who are not well versed in science fiction. Here is a great breakdown of the ending and what I think makes the most sense (the first explanation): http://screenrant.com/edge-of-tomorrow-ending-spoilers-time-travel/2/

Wow, what a great summer action movie. This is what I look for when I go into a big action-packed blockbuster. It's smart, it has a great sci-fi premise, it's action-packed, it has interesting characters and character dynamics, and it has a lot of humor in it.

Let's address the humor, shall we? This movie had so many moments that made me laugh. It really used its central conceit well, making light of many of the deaths (especially in the outstanding sequence of Rita continually shooting Cage, despite his pleas). I also love the line "Don't shoot him again." The editor of the movie should definitely get props.

The movie could've gone wrong in so many ways due to the inherently tedious nature of the plot. Each time some progress is made, you know that Cage is probably going to die again, so sometimes it can feel like there's no forward motion. But the genius thing is how the movie skips many key sequences of Cage gradually learning, yet still manages to provide enough information in each scene to keep the viewer aware of what's going on. Going back to that line, "Don't shoot him again," it becomes immediately clear that Cage and Rita have gone on this mission many times already. Lots of scenes provide necessary background information to remind the viewer that they're not seeing EVERY repetition. In unseen scenes, Cage learns extra information about General Brigham, in addition to the rest of the military team, to prove himself later. He nails every little move through sheer repetition (like the hilarious scene of Cage getting run over by a truck and then successfully rolling a moment later).

And yet the movie is also able to use that uncertainty about how many times Cage has repeated the same day to its advantage to purposely confuse the viewer, like the scene when he admits Rita always dies at the same point. It allows for a lot of great surprises as the viewer watches Cage effortlessly dodge blows and sarcastically predict the exact words someone will say.

Lastly, there's Rita, who's just a great character. I'm not sure why I enjoyed her so much, but she's the perfect 'strong female character.' She's a total badass, but she doesn't look masculine. She's really smart, but can concede that Cage is the one with whom the real power lies. But even though she exists primarily to further Cage's arc and to help him on his mission, she's a strong and intelligent character in her own right. She's the one with the intelligence and the power throughout most of the movie, and it's great to see her training Cage.

The one negative element of the entire movie for me was the kiss between Cage and Rita. Honestly, I'm very tolerant of predictable romances in movies, and I wasn't even opposed to a romance in this movie, but the kiss itself seemed out of place based on Rita's character. I would've preferred that the scene just ended with Rita saying, "I wish I had more time to get to know you" or whatever, and then left it like that. There'd been some sexual tension throughout the movie, but I would've preferred it to be tension that doesn't really get resolved in any explosive way.

I know a lot of people probably thought the ending of the movie was too pat and happy, and I can definitely understand that. There's definitely something appealing about the thought of both Rita and Cage dying and sacrificing themselves to save the world. At the same time, though, I just love the idea of Cage living to tell the tale, and coming back and finding Rita and bonding with her because they're the only two people who've experienced the time loops, and them actually getting the time to get to know each other like Rita had hoped for. See, you can tell that I really do like the idea of them as a couple; it's just that I didn't think the kiss belonged in the movie. They could've completely cut that out and ended the movie the same way, with Cage laughing at Rita. That was a perfect last shot.

This dash of cinematic junk food boasts a crisp, chocolatey effects extravaganza for an outer shell and a wash of sticky, creamy sci-fi curiosity at its core. The concept is tricky but fascinating, a bit stretched but not so far that it completely shatters the illusion. It's basically Groundhog Day meets Independence Day, with Tom Cruise wearing a great big suit of mechanized armor as its showpiece. Go into battle, kill some aliens, meet a grisly demise, respawn at the checkpoint and try it all over again; that's basically the plot. It's best when Cruise is relegated to mere rapid-fire cannon fodder, trying like hell to make the most of his chances and failing miserably. The ride gets markedly less entertaining, and more humdrum, as it slides into sentimentality and finality. The ending is a real whiff, too, and undoubtedly colors my memory of the better bits that I'd enjoyed previously. It smacks of a last-minute rewrite, something that's utterly at-odds with the dashes of smart, dark material that had spiced things earlier in the ride. A film that wants to be flashy and ballsy, but instead finds itself tamed and neutered.

This movie is exactly what most people are saying about it; Groundhog's Day meets Starship Troopers; to that I would only add, with the ending of Cruise's last sci-movie. Director Liman, who already impressed me years ago with Mr. & Ms Smith, once again delivers on a quirky OTT popcorn flick with another strange romance. Not to imply that there is much romance in this movie, but although its plainly obvious, Liman still managed to surprise me when Cruise's Cage begins to fall for Blunt's Rita. The movie wisely capitalizes on Cruise's smugness and endlessly kills him onscreen until that self-serving smile is gone and Cruise becomes all we really want from him, which is action hero mode.

I feel bad for Blunt, who now has a a trilogy of under-appreciated sci-fi flicks, with Edge of Tomorrow joining Adjustment Bureau and Looper. Her performance is a strong one rooted in the physical, but lacks some of the charisma and personality of previous turns, nonetheless she holds our interest well and holds more than her own against her costar. In fact this movie makes a better fit in her filmography then it does Cruise's. The time travel and its consequences on characters echoes the mechanics seen in Looper and the fate-changing in Bureau. Likewise the mapping out of the battlefield choices and the kill-death-repeat nature of the movie reminded me allot of Adjustment Bureau.

The special FX are really impressive with the mech-gear that we all wished we'd seen in the Starship Trooper movies. The aliens are pretty cool, reminding me a little of The Matrix, mixed with the Drej from Titan A.E. The finale set in war-torn Paris are visually striking indeed, with a fallen Eiffel Tower and a flooded Louvre.

The movie entertained and pleased me well until its final coda, one that defies sense and seems tagged on just for the sake of having a happy ending for the romantically minded. Aside from that minor quibble, I'd say this movie is sure to please those looking for a good sci-fi flick in the same vein of Blunt's previous entries or something to watch after Starship Troopers.

I realize I'm starting off with a nitpick, particularly since this is a sci-fi film, but isn't it incredibly irresponsible to throw a person without a day of combat training, just to teach him a lesson because you don't like the guy.  In a movie that's about Cage, Tom Cruise, being stuck in a time loop after killing one of the invading aliens' Alphas, which is only happens 1 in 6 million, and getting its blood all over him, which causes him to gain the Omega ability to reset the day.  So complaining about the fact that no military would ever throw an untrained officer in the middle of a big ass battle seems minor.  But it's ridiculous, that's why there's a division of labor.  Soldiers fight and everyone else does what they were assigned to do and never the twain shall meet, so to speak.  Silly nitpick out of the way, this film is pretty damn great.  The time loop concept, obviously, isn't a new idea but this film finds a way to make it feel fresh with interesting character development, excellent action sequences and a clever script that gets the most out of each scene.  I don't think it's bound to reinvent the genre and bring about a sci-fi action film renaissance, but it does do everything exceptionally well.  The film finds ways to combine comedy, sci-fi, and action into one tight little neat package.  It's all working together and one element doesn't undercut the other.  I don't think the film, however, is as thought-provoking as it could've been.  I don't think any film has explored the mental effects this type of situation can have on someone.  Reliving each day over and over and over and over again.  Sure, you can change certain things and alter others, but you're essentially living through the same day ad nauseam.  Particularly if you have to see one person, whom you may have had romantic links to or just really close friends, die over and over again, without being able to do anything to change it.  The film even has some of that with Rita going through this very same thing when she was stuck in her time loop, prior to the film's events of course.  And they also go through this with Cage and how he's unable to save Rita, no matter what he does, in a certain situation.  Granted, it probably couldn't have focused on this too heavily since there's is an invasion going on that could end with the extinction of all human life, but still, it would be cool to see a film do this some time.  Of course, that's not what the film was meant to be, so I'm not holding that against them, and it's not affecting the score at all.  The character development is quite strong.  Rita is one of the best female characters in any action film in recent memory.  I mean that in the sense that, yes, she may be supporting Cage through his mission, getting him to where he needs to be as far as his abilities are concerned AND saving the world, but she's also pretty badass herself.  It's a nice social commentary on gender roles and I think it works for the best for this film.  If there's one point that I think weakens both characters is when they share a kiss in the climax.  It felt so out of place.  On the one hand, it could've been done, since Rita initiated the kiss, that it was her accepting the fact that neither of them would survive this moment.  But it felt more like 'we have two attractive leads, we HAVE to have them kiss'.  It doesn't really work in the context of the story.  It's completely unnecessary in my opinion.  It doesn't really change my view of the film, but it does, very slightly, hurt the characters.  The film very much plays out like a video game.  In the sense that when you die, you get to restart over earlier and you're the only one aware of what happened.  Ironically enough, the book this film is based on, was heavily inspired by the author's time spent playing video games.  So I'm not sure if this is a conscious decision in this adaptation's part or not.  Then again, any action film with a time loop concept will always be reminiscent of video games.  I also read somewhere that this is a meta commentary on summer blockbusters and how numbing the whole thing can be.  Watching the same movie over and over with only slight deviations.  I don't entirely agree with that, but I can see how a person would think that.  It's a well-thought out theory.  I say this because this is not only exclusive to summer blockbusters.  It might be more noticeable with them, since there's so much more of a promotional focus on these films, but it's not exclusive to that particular genre.  The special effects are great, as is the action choreography.  Everything in this film happens for a reason, everything plays a part into how the film climaxes.  There's no filler in this film and that's always a good thing.  Particularly when there seems to be so much padding in many other films.  But I digress, this is definitely worth your time.  It's not gonna make my top 10 of 2014, but it finds a nice balance and it manages to find a way to appeal to both men and women equally.  Not many action films can say that they found a way to create a compelling female character without resorting to stereotypes.  Great film.

There are three reasons why I didn't saw this movie right away: Tom Cruise - War Movie - Alien Invasions. Can you count the number of movies he played with similar genre? You've got to hand it to Japan though. I don't know if this movie was adapted wholly from its source, but Japan is indeed a country of amazing ideas. I'm pleased to say that this is one of them. If they can make a story of war and aliens to be exciting, then it IS exciting, regardless to the fact that it's not even your thing. 

Though at first it started off like your regular war alien invasion war movie, when the concept of time-loop sank in, it became a totally different experience. I found myself laughing and enthusiastically excited about what's going on next, and that's not an easy accomplishment. A praise is in order for the team that managed to adapt this story into such amazing and brilliant screenplay. Not only it felt smart, but also worked even when the concept itself is not something new. Sure, nitpicking will draw out numbers of issues, but it's amazing how it was able to drag you into the story, kept you in place eager to learn more about the final outcome. I know for sure it had that effect on me. But really, the biggest highlight of the movie would be the tough slashing Emily Blunt, playing the deadly soldier Rita Vrasivksi. Her commanding presence stole the scene and brought integrity to her character, though in a way it's a testament to Mr Cruise for being able to steer himself away from hogging on the spotlight. Their interaction felt organic, and Rita is a strong character that it's obvious why we ended up rooting for her to survive. 

If I had the chance to return to the past and redo things I've done wrong, I'd totally do it especially if there's a way to end the process whenever I want. One thing I will definitely do though, is to watch this at the theatre when it premiered. 

It's such a disappointment that this movie didn't get a much much better public response, because it truly deserved it. A movie this good should've attracted more box office numbers, especially with plenty of rave reviews pouring to support it. I do understand its 'lack of appeal' though. Echoing my own three points I mentioned above, it's possible audience have grown fatigue with the lead actor, or the theme of the movie itself.

Action Groundhog Day. Cruise's character starts off endearingly useless, but is, predictably, the usual smarmy super hero by the end. It throws away its premise for the last act and then tacks on a predictable Hollywood ending.

Referred to originally as 'All You Need is Kill' which was the title of the sci-fi novel this movie is adapted from. Since that title was poo-pooed by the vast majority despite it being the actual original title of the material...'Edge of Tomorrow' was thusly born which personally I think sounds like a tacky 70's sci-fi TV show or perhaps a Dr Who episode. Over time that too was also apparently poo-pooed by the vast majority, and so the movie has also come to be known as 'LIVE. DIE. REPEAT.' On reflection this is actually a solid title.

Now I don't know anything of the original source material so I can only go by what the movie presents to me naturally. Set in a near future where humans are at war with an alien race that is threatening to wipe us out for good...original much? So its business as usual for this sci-fi actioner, the clever twist being amongst the alien ranks are a special larger breed called Alpha's. These Alpha's have a unique genetic trait that when they get killed they somehow automatically respawn again at the beginning of their day, turning back the clock and reliving the day they died. This gives them an advantage in the war plus it opens up some pretty humongous questions about these creatures like...how the fuck?! Do these things ever die then?? How does their blood even do this? and when Cruise gets infected with this gift do the other Alpha's lose it?

So first things first the film introduces us to the human element and Mr Cruise, I must say its very refreshing to see Cruise actually playing a cowardly whining desk jockey instead of some super soldier...no wait. Although I still can't quite work out why exactly General Brendan Gleeson wants Cruise on the front line, merely to record the battle? anyone can do that. It also baffles me how Cruise is somehow dumped in with the grunts after being knocked out and no one seems to recognise him, its like he's a new recruit and no one has ever heard of him. I'm pretty sure in that situation some one would know of you or you'd be able to contact some one higher but anyway...I guess everyone was in on this dastardly plan to get Cruise in the thick of it.

The military side of things all seems very familiar truth be told, I dare not mention James Cameron's 'Aliens' but...it all looks like James Cameron's 'Aliens'. Most of the technology feels very space Marine-esque with the obligatory predictable bunch of space Marine-esque tough nut characters all led by Bill Paxton as an aged Hudson. There's the tough as nails Latino looking female, the fat guy, the crazy-ass guy, the slightly clever guy, the token black guy and various other headcases...military unit 101. What I don't get is why the leading kickass female played by Blunt carries a bigass sword...in a world of huge guns and powered exoskeletons (with mightily powered shoulder cannons ala 'Predator') why would you need a sword? Sure it looks cool but it makes no sense. Oh and we see her small team of elite special ops fighters with her at one point. All looking very imposing with their helmets adorned with skull motifs...where the hell did they go??!!

Personally I thought the casting for the grunts was poor with all coming across as little more than stereotypical cliches portrayed badly. None are memorable with no standout lines or moments and they just looked like standard videogame fodder. This leads me to the aliens which again I didn't really like, why does everything these days have tentacles? These things merely came across as a big ball of spikes that zipped around like Sonic the Hedgehog, impossible to make out properly and unthreatening because they just look like blurs of tentacles. Oh and they have acid blood?? errrr...('Aliens'). I also found it hard to believe that the human military superiors refused to believe their leading scientist on the alien genetic makeup. This guy is there for that purpose and he knows what's going on but no one believes him...soooo what's the point in him being there?

Visually the film is pretty awesome...in the first half hour whilst we see Cruise fighting on the beaches WWII style. Its all heavily influenced by the Normandy invasion of WWII (see 'Saving Private Ryan') with lots of mega sized vehicles coming out of the sea and the sky, troops storming the beach and being cut down easily, trench fighting, mighty explosions lifting waves of sand into the air etc...its very impressive and looks fantastic. Its also really fun to watch Cruise get killed time after time as he tries to navigate his way to certain people or locations trying to recall what to do and when. Hell...seeing Cruise die in a movie is unique in itself! Watching this character refine his skills and learning what to do and where to duck is actually really cool despite sounding dull, you kinda want more of that in the end. Once things start to move away from this scenario and the plot slowly progresses the movie does lose its exciting visual appeal and things become slightly mundane. 

Things do get a tad slow towards the finale and the actual ending is also weak, it builds up so well but can't deliver in the end. Its a shame because the first half of the movie is really explosive, fast paced and wonderfully thrilling but its just falls away from the midway point. It also becomes typically daft after Cruise loses his special powers yet still manages to survive some incredible falls and situations, so in the end its back to the regular invincible superman Mr Cruise again.

At first I didn't realise it but upon reflection it dawned on me that this project is actually a very smart little videogame movie. The entire concept of dying and respawning straight away at a certain location or save point is of course a videogame concept. It does feel like your watching someone playing a new Xbox One (Playstation 4) shoot em up as they work their way through the levels. Personally I liked the first half, the build up is great but the pay off is meh. Casting was also mediocre in my humble opinion as no one really stands out in my mind and nothing is really memorable accept for seeing Cruise getting wiped off the board in a variety of ways (the hook). I can't help but feel the whole movie would have been even better had it been set in its native Japan with a slightly lesser known cast or at least not as big. That said its definitely a solid sci-fi action movie with a decent plot, I just feel it had the potential to be an outright classic but just swung and missed. On a final note the end credits music track is bloody awful.

A race of aliens called Mimics has taken over continental Europe. General Brigham (Brendan Gleeson), head of humanity's United Defense Force, orders Major William Cage (Tom Cruise), a public affairs officer and former advertising executive, to cover combat on the beaches of France during the next day's assault on the Mimics. Cage objects to the dangerous assignment and threatens to use his public relations skills to turn the public against Brigham when the casualties start increasing from the invasion. General Brigham has Cage arrested; Cage is knocked out during an ensuing escape attempt. He wakes in handcuffs at a forward operating base at Heathrow Airport and discovers he has been labeled a deserter and put on combat duty for the invasion under the command of Master Sergeant Farell (Bill Paxton). The invasion is a disaster for the humans. Cage manages to kill a large Mimic but dies as he is sprayed with its acid-like blood. He then wakes up at Heathrow the previous morning. No one believes his story that he knows the invasion will fail. He repeats the loop of dying on the beach and waking at Heathrow until he encounters Sergeant Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt). She recognizes his ability to anticipate events and tells him to locate her the next time he "wakes up". Cage finds Vrataski at Heathrow. Together they meet up with Dr. Carter (Noah Taylor), a former government scientist and expert in Mimic biology. Cage learns that the kind of Mimic he killed in his first loop, an "Alpha", resets time when it is killed to give the Mimics an advantage in battle. Cage inherited this ability when he was doused in the Alpha's blood as they both died. Vrataski had this ability in the recent but only successful battle but lost it after receiving a blood transfusion. She tells Cage that they must hunt the Mimics' hive mind, the Omega. And, as Cage and Vrataski take the fight to the Mimics, each repeated encounter gets them one step closer to defeating the enemy...

Doug Liman directed the film based on a screenplay adapted from the Japanese light novel "All You Need Is Kill" by Hiroshi Sakurazaka. Cruise Sci-Fi alien thriller "Oblivion" was a doze for me despite its great cinematography and visuals. So, I was hoping for something better in the genre from Cruise this time around and "Edge Of Tomorrow" delivers for sure. It´s always tricky with time looping movies since how many times can you repeat the same scenario before the audience lose the interest. "Edge Of Tomorrow" is balancing on that line for a moment, but manages to keep it on the right side and it doesn´t get lost in the progress. I like the development of Tom Cruise character from a terrified public affairs officer in combat to becoming a hardened soldier. He fits the role as Cage and so does the talented and beautiful Emily Blunt in her role as Rita. Love the scene when she is doing yoga in the battle training room and being approched by Cage. She manages to balance her role as the "Full Metal Bitch" and yet being vulnerable at the same time. Justin Chang of Variety called "Edge of Tomorrow" "a cleverly crafted and propulsively executed sci-fi thriller" and said the film was director Doug Liman's best since The Bourne Identity (2002). Chang said the screenwriters, with the assistance of the editors, "tell their story in a breezy narrative shorthand (and at times, sleight-of-hand), transforming what must surely be an unbelievably tedious gauntlet for our hero into a deft, playful and continually involving viewing experience". The critic said of the relationship of Cruise and Blunt's characters, "Liman handles it with a pleasing lightness of touch that extends to the proceedings as a whole." He also commended the visual effects of the "expertly designed Mimics" as well as Dion Beebe's cinematography. It´s hard to not think of Verhoeven´s "Starship Troopers", but "Edge Of Tomorrow" carries its own uniqueness, weight and strength. An alternative, darker ending was considered for the film as follows: As they approach Paris in the drop-ship, Cage briefs the soldiers that they must not kill an Alpha or it will cause a time loop and "we'll be right back here having this conversation, and we won't even know it." During fighting, one of the soldiers gets separated, then confronts and kills an Alpha. The audience sees the Omega reset the day and witnesses the same conversation as before about not killing an Alpha, but then an attack starts and the audience knows that the Mimics have the upper hand as the movie ends. The actual released movie has scenes in the drop-ship where the soldiers are reviewing Cage's warning and one says "Do not kill an Alpha or we'll never even know we had this conversation and they'll know we're coming". Also, when the Mimics begin firing on the ship, somebody yells "They know we're coming, Cage!" These scenes were probably filmed for the alternate ending. I think "Edge Of Tomorrow" is really well made, intriguing, popcorn action fun and the CGI is top notch. And I don´t have any issues with the ending.

Dying again-and-again and coming back to the same day may seem like an advantage, but it's quite a painful ordeal. And being the only one to sustain the memory of all the events (through every death) is even more painful.

The special effects are incredible, the sound effects and background score are well in tone with the film, and humour is used quite efficiently to tell the story.

Review:
I quite enjoyed this movie, which has non-stop intense action/drama from beginning to end. The director added a witty script along with a decent concept which is a mixture between Aliens and Groundhog Day. Although the premise is about a man who relives the same day every time that he gets killed, you do see different parts of that day so your not going through the same thing over and over again. It was cleverly put together by the director, who covered every aspect of the storyline, and I'm glad that it didn't go down the soppy love story route and it just stuck to a full out action movie. The weird looking creatures made the movie intense and dramatic, even though they looked similar to the ones in the Matrix, and the suits were pretty impressive. Basically, it's everything that you expect from a Tom Cruise blockbuster action movie and I personally enjoyed it more than Oblivion and Jack Reacher. Enjoyable!

Round-Up:
Tom Cruise really isn't showing any signs of slowing down at the ripe age of 52. He still looks pretty good for his age and he's still pulling off a lot of his own stunts. In this movie, he plays his role extremely well because he adds a little wit to the puzzling situation. The chemistry between Cruise and Blunt was great but it could have done with a couple more decent actors as his crew. Its good to see Bill Paxton back in a decent movie but the director should have used Brian Gleeson a bit more. Anyway it's definitely worth a watch for its originality and great concept and I personally think that you will see something different every time that you watch it.Â

I've been thinking recently that Tom Cruise is on the precipice of a career revitalization. It's weird to think like that since I don't think most of America thinks of Cruise as anything less than a money-making A-list actor.

His journey from biggest actor in Hollywood to couch-jumping crazy was remarkably short. It's been a long time since that Oprah appearance--over nine years. But the second that Oprah episode ended, everything sort of changed. The Tom Cruise mystique had been stripped away. Instead of being the "it" actor, he was just a guy who was crazy. His Scientology religion didn't much endear him in the public eye, either. And it seemed as though he and Katie Holmes just shriveled out of public view to start their life.

Which isn't to say he hasn't been around since 2005. Mission Impossible III released in 2006. Tropic Thunder in 2008, while a small roll, showed that he still had screen charisma. MI: Ghost Protocol rolled in as a nice nostalgic film. Little could be looked at on his IMDB page between 2005 and 2011 as being much more than a former star getting random roles. Nothing sticks out as being anything other than the slow, grinding halt of a once massive career that no longer exists.

But over the last couple of years something seems to be improving. You could say it started with Ghost Protocol, though a 4th installment of a series still looking to top the first Mission Impossible movie is hardly the best example, though it does make for a fine stepping stone. No, the more interesting movie is Jack Reacher from 2012. While not an amazingly creative film, Jack Reacher showed us again what makes Cruise such an engaging action hero. And then Oblivion in 2013 reminded us that he's had a long history with edgy sci-fi films.

Which brings us to the awkwardly titled Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow.

It's a mixture of Groundhog Day and War of the Worlds. And it's not perfect; leans too heavily on some shifty logic. But it's hard to care while watching.

Live Die Repeat showcases an awe-inspiring sequence of events, encased in a gritty sci-fi/war environment, and Tom Cruise making us feel like it's 1996 again. The biggest downside is that despite the high ratings, it seems like most people are ignoring it like they've ignored most of Cruise's stuff in a post-2005 world.

Still, despite how fun Jack Reacher and Oblivion were, Live Die Repeat is a movie that is not only fun, but just really good in most respects. Hopefully it portends good things for Cruise movies in the future.

Sci-fi movie set in not a very distant future; weird looking aliens (a cross between a lion, an octopus and a gremlin) are invading Earth and winning. In the midst of the ongoing fight to repel them a Major that has never been to combat is sent to the front line. When Cage (Cruise) refuses to do so he is debased and dumped in the battlefield anyway with absolutely no idea of how to use his hi-tech combat suit. During the struggle he accidentally kills one of the "omega" a top ranking alien that in dying passes him the skill to reset the day. Cage relives the battle day over and over again trying to locate and kill the other omega that is lurking somewhere in Europe. During his numerous "try outs" he meets the war poster girl, Rita Vratasky (Blunt), a warrior that teaches him how to navigate and master the skill that might save humankind.
This is a "Groundhog day" of the future, a man caught in the same day until he learns his way out but instead of a comedy here we have a thriller format. It is easy to get a little lost in the many twists of the story, it happens often in films where the time factor is stretched and distorted, however it is, in the overall, an engaging epic with loads of action and fights and with no space to get bored. This is a typical Hollywood product with good storytelling and very appealing and sophisticated special effects which fans of the gender are meant to love. The chemistry between the two main leads also helps to make this a very round film.

Coming from Doug Liman who gave us The Bourne Identity and The Bourne Ultimatum, Edge of Tomorrow is a clever presentation of something much more complicated to fathom than it seems in the actual movie. Tom Cruise (Major William Cage) is thrown into combat against spider like supersonic alien creatures and dies after killing the alpha. He wakes up back at the base. He goes through the same routine again, only to die and to wake up again. And again. And again. He has to decipher and make sense of it all, in the midst of an invasion. 

The omega mother alien being has the ability to alter time, in order to better understand its enemies weaknesses. The story seems to get more and more complicated over time but has been explained in such a well ordered fashion, that Doug Liman deserves applause here. By the end of the movie, you feel refreshed, intelligent and content with an action thriller that could not have been handled better. 

Great support by Emily Blunt as Rita Vrataski. You will be so immersed in the experience, that your popcorn will remain untouched.

Edge of Tomorrow is a slick, intelligent, interesting movie with a good premise. It's a film that nobody saw and turned out to be just a below average grosser thanks to the poor trailer and the bad promotions. People might have expected the same level of intelligence from Cruise's last sci-fi film, Oblivion(2013)( another film with a good Tom Cruise performance). Edge of Tomorrow doesn't provide much seriousness, but thanks to it's cast, it provides much entertainment. It's no Source Code(2011) or Snowpiercer(2014), and that's due to the lacking of emotional quotient. Tom Cruise alone is needed to carry on with such a project, but his depleting fan following is not a cause for joy. This is perhaps the first Doug Liman film that I have seen and his direction is ok. What's this film really like? It's like the terminator meeting alien with a Saving Private Ryan setting overall and sci-fi elements which resemble gaming. Doug Liman (Bourne Identity and the guilty pleasure Jumper) delivers his first film since Fair Game (2010) with this adaptation of Japanese novel All You Need Is Kill and stars Tom Cruise as William Cage, a demoted military Major who ends up repeating the same day over and over in a fight against an alien horde. Joining Groundhog Day and Source Code as "repeat-day" films the movie shares some themes from those including the learning new things each day, re-planning situations based on knowledge gained as well as a musical montage to show a "training" section - here Andie McDowell's slaps are replaced with Emily Blunt's robotic training claws that batter and bruise Cruise. The time loop narrative is effective and Cruise ultimately gets better at fighting the aliens but the movie also has a great supporting cast who help deliver the high concept plot. Blunt plays an elite special forces fighter who is used to promote the cause to new recruits but who also knows more about the aliens than originally thought, whilst the much-missed Bill Paxton (Aliens, Twister) returns to sci-fi as a bombastic Sergeant putting Cruise through his paces. Brendan Gleeson is a nice addition but underused as a misinformed General and the European settings of London and Paris were a fine change from the regular California locales that audiences are used to from such summer blockbusters. From the battle-ready mech-suits - which were much better utilised than the similar body-weapons of 2013's Elysium - to the cleverly structured narrative, Cruise delivers a much better sci-fi performance than the stale Oblivion from last year with a twisty concept that (almost) rivals his stunning turn in Spielberg's Minority Report. A big blockbuster with brains, brawn, brute force and Blunt, Edge of Tomorrow is a movie you'll no doubt come back to again and again. 8/10 Midlands Movies Mike

The movie lives or dies with two corner stones. The brain bug *cough* *cough* setting and time. 

I have to admit that the visuals are very well made, but the movie is shallow even for a Hollywood production. Tom Cruise should be able to demonstrate a change in a character in his (combat) boots, but all I see is a tourist with a happy-go-lucky mentally most of the time, unless he doesn't have to talk and just need to point a weapon somewhere. Even when he tries he doesn't deliver anything deeper then a small frown. 
Maybe it's because it's PG 13 but the movie feels like what happens is too bright, like a walk in the park with the accidentally stepping into a puddle instead of a world wide conflict. The other characters don't have much time to shine, which is part of the concept but also centers the whole world around one actor who is doing a half-hearted job.

All in all I like the concept to combine two great ideas and the visuals, but the execution in the acting department leaves much to be desired. 
Maybe they should have taken a closer look on Starship Troopers and Groundhog Day and chosen someone who has a wider range in acting?

Edge of Tomorrow is a fresh look at the age old sci fi genre that based on alien invasions and courages humans who defeat them. And its the modern day Independence Day movie and it seriously rocks the foundations of sci fi that came out lately. Huge production, staggering CG and awesome acting makes Edge of Tomorrow one of the best action sci fis lately. In not so distant future the world is invaded by an alien race known as Mimics. The world is at war and seems like the humans are capable of defeating them. Major Cage (Tom Cruise) who is a publicity agent for the ARMY than a real soldier is sent to the front line of the crucial battle against Mimics without his will. Cage finds himself terrified and helpless when the battle becomes bloodier and a massacre of humans than expected. But coincidentally he discovers a way to manipulate time and relive the same battle and perfect it to realize that the aliens can be defeated using a different strategy. Rita (Emily Blunt) a fellow soldier joins him for the ride. 

The plot here is very creative. When the real time travel or time loop hits the center stage the whole phase and the feel of the movie quickly changes. This is where it gets the true edge against other similar alien invasion movies and the tight grip remains till the very end. While some viewers can be utterly confused by the fact of this time loop and the repeating scenes Im sure no one would lose interest of the movie because of it. The element of surprise is very good and movie throws in some real candy for the viewers without delays. The flow and the phase is indeed appealing and the peaks and off peaks are well balanced. However as mentioned earlier the plot has many weak points and as a sci fi that makes sense Edge of Tomorrow is far behind. 

Tom has a history of alien invasion movies such as War of the Worlds (2005) and one of my personal favorite Oblivion (2013). Edge of Tomorrow is another jewel for his collection proving that he is still hot as he used to be decades back. Emily Blunt is sharp and very well fit for her role. The duo does a perfect job on the set and they spark while the aliens bleed. 

What makes Edge of Tomorrow is so good is its action and animation. They hit you very unexpectedly and some scenes are so majestic and detailed that you might feel that one viewing is not good enough. Starting from the production to the finishing touch of sound this movie is a true action flick and no one can say otherwise.

Cleverly constructed sci-fi actioner sees Cruise as a cowardly military bureaucrat ordered into the front line of a war between humans and alien invaders. A very familiar Heinlein-like set up, which is then completely deconstructed and revitalized by the film's central twist: each time Cruise dies, he wakes up again at the beginning of the day. This device (before seen also with great success in romantic comedy Groundhog Day) gives way to a playful transition from coward to hero, defeat to victory, all sprinkled with liberal doses of black humour, and some romance by way of Emily Blunt's character, who is effectively more butch than Cruise here. Do not write this off as merely another big dumb Hollywood movie. It's got wits to satisfy the intellect, and enough brawn to satisfy that need for bug and dumb.

Cruise plays a wimp Officer who has never seen combat who is dropped straight into battle against a brutal alien invasion. He dies within minutes of landing on the battlefield but wakes up to find he didn't die, he ends up repeating the same day over and over again, in doing so finds that, with the help of Emily Blunt's war hero, they can find a way to destroy the evil alien forces and save Earth. It's a decent film, humourous and comical in its action while Cruise relives his groundhog day of war and realises he should take notes on how to survive a little longer. This is Cruise's film with everyone else just replaying the day over and over so there's not much growth for any other character. If you want a decent action/sci-fi with a sense of humour, you can't go past this.

"Groundhog Day: ...To the Extreme"! No, this is more like "Source Code", only with even more action, explosions, warfare and, of course, aliens, which sounds awesome, up until you see that the director is Doug Liman. Now, I like Liman just fine, but he couldn't keep "The Bourne Identity" or "Mr. & Mrs. Smith" consistently exciting, and in case that doesn't scare you enough, they already blanded up the title of the novel upon which this film is based. "All you need is kill, all you need is kill, all you need is kill-kill; kill is all you need!" That is a bizarre title for an over-the-top sci-fi film which features mech suits, so, naturally, this film is based on something from Japan. Even more natural is Tom Cruise's presence in this role, because he looks like he's been repeating the same day since he was at the edge of thirty. Speaking of repetition, I'm going to be having Stevie Nicks' "Edge of Seventeen" on repeat in my head all day now, but the fact of the matter is that Tom Cruise is still awesome at thirty-going-on-seventy, and knows how to pick some quality science fiction... like "Oblivion" (So, what's everyone's problem with that movie, again?), with this film being decent, but not even tight science-fiction.

Not even the telling of this sci-fi story is tight, for although monotony is, of course, a major theme here, it backs a story that isn't exactly meaty enough to warrant a runtime of almost two hours, thus, things get to be more repetitious than they should be, amidst all of the excess, even in tonal layers. There's a great deal of humor in this film, and plenty of it proves to be fairly sharp, with more than a few moments which are cheesy, maybe even a hint obnoxious in its approach to such low-brow styles as slapstick, which isn't to say that these heights in fluff consistently break tensions a little jarringly. Comic style even overshadows substance, but really, one of the deepest dents in this film are produced by overstylization, much of which is noisy in its molding a fast pace that is fun, especially for a Doug Liman film, but wears you down and thins a sense of focus, no matter how hard the writers try to downsize the focus of this sci-fi thriller. There's not a whole lot of substance to betray with overstylization in this superficial flick, which offers no extensive background to its sci-fi mythology, and not much nuance to characterization, resulting in a serious superficiality that would be easier to forgive if the telling of a thin story wasn't of such decent quality, or if the story was at all original. There's something a little fresh about this particular amalgamation of tropes, but all this story is is tropes, familiar sci-fi and action fluff piece themes that are generic, making for a predictable narrative that is worn down enough by all of the inconsistencies in pacing and tone, and by a lack of realization in stylistic control and substance. A couple elements in writing and most all elements of direction are fairly strong, so much so that they can go into making a more rewarding sci-fi, glimpses of which are found throughout the early and latter acts, and here and there throughout the final product's body, but all but lost amidst all of the underwhelming aspects that make this not much more than your usual sci-fi action blockbuster. Hopes and concerns are met in equal quantity, and although that means the loss of bona fide reward value, it also means the film's coming to the brink of rewarding, partly on the back of technical sharpness.

Technical proficiency even leads to solid cinematography, whose well-defined grit captures a sense of tension in this flick, and offers some handsome imagery to catch your eye, almost as much as outstanding visual effects that craft anything from distinguished alien effects to all sorts of explosive spectacle that is at its most marvelous in the heat of battle. Tensions suffer from style, but only outside of the battlefields, because just about every action scene, while a little confusing and very noisy, is awe-inspired in its technical brilliance and intense in its extensive staging, which actually marks heights in the tension. There's a lot of potential for that sort of sci-fi/military intensity in a story of this nature, because even though no aspect of this sci-fi subject matter is refreshing, they all go into forming interesting ideas about time looping, and taking advantage of it for the sake of strategy during warfare that threatens the human race itself. The script by the hilariously named writing team of Christopher McQuarrie and Jez and John-Henry Butterworth betrays this potential through unevenness in tone and structure, and through a lack of extensive attention to background and nuance, thus rendering a potentially juicy thriller near-inconsequential, but not without featuring plenty of highlights in wit and tight spots in plotting to hold your attention when it comes to fluff. If substance has engagement value, then it thrives on the performances, with Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt sharing solid charisma and chemistry to augment charm, eventually incorporating some dramatic touches that sell a sense of urgency and consequence in a superficially drawn narrative that doesn't offer the depth that has been found in certain other action films of this nature, if not by this director. Doug Liman is known for his steady pacing, and I've certainly done my share of joking about that, but here, I am pleasantly surprised that he keeps pacing consistently brisk, tightening up a sense of momentum in this overlong affair, and keeping up high entertainment value, until finding an opportunity to work in some thoughtfulness that, as much as the acting, gives some weight to all of the fluff and what have you, and therefore provides glimpses into what could have been. As I mentioned earlier, the first act's formula is fresh enough for you to be hooked, in spite of the superficialities, and when it comes to the latter acts, substance finally thrives amidst the style, and leads to some compelling thrills, of which there are so very little during the body that the final product cannot achieve the rewarding heights that it culminates with, although that isn't to say that the film is ever less than reasonably engaging as a fun and sometimes weighty, if ultimately misguided watching.

When the day is done for good, too much momentum is lost under the weight of an excessive structure, tonal unevenness, overstylization and a lack of extensive nuance which thin a sense of substance to an already blandly generic and predictable plot, until the final product is unable to reward, even though it is brought to the, if you will, edge, by the handsome cinematography, spectacular effects, stellar action sequences and interesting story ideas that, when backed by clever aspects to writing, endearing performances and chemistry between Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt, and direction that is more inspired than it probably should be with a film like this, make Doug Liman's "Edge of Tomorrow" almost as compelling as it is thoroughly entertaining as an explosive take on a time loop story concept.

Based on a Japanese fiction, Edge of Tomorrow's uses its central theme of reliving time to bring about a captivating and entertaining flick with humor that relies on the warping of time to surprise the characters and the audience simultaneously thrilling us with action that is granted by the CGI battles between the human forces and the aliens. Although it has to be said that if it weren't for the main characters of Cruise and Blunt, this would've turned out be just a generic action flick: they bring about their own wits and charm to their roles as well as showing tight on-screen chemistry.

Plotwise, the premise is about a last hope of survival resting in the hands of the unlikely hero, or in this case a coward who's even afraid to fight. Tom Cruise's character is one of the last means for the survival of the world, where they must complete an audacious journey through enemy infested territories to destroy their leader. The story once set up and details exposed takes off plunging us into montage sequences of the same day and events repeating on each other and the evolution of the main character through his several comedic and violent deaths from which he gains wisdom and eventually succeeds in instilling himself infinite courage. We are drawn into support him and his band of rowdies because we feel when it comes to the case of the destruction of the planet there is no real point in discrimination, as any one of them can become potential heroes.

Tom's character and that of Emily share a fine on-screen chemistry where the two has to set-apart their lack of compatibility in personality and work together for the survival of mankind. Often the female is shown as being the dominant one and the one who has the grit and boundless courage to go ahead while Tom is reluctantly entered into his role and the constant failures he encounters saps his motivation. There is conflict because of the mis-match of personalities, which is palpable as on-screen tension but one that slowly withers away as trust and affection seems to grow to a point we are made to feel for their unrequited love. 

The film for a sci-fi action flick relies less on visual drama comparatively and the entertainment of the flick from long suspense of the inevitable conflict, the humour that comes along the junp-cut narrative and the star power of these two actors. But the other real stars here are the stunt team and the suits. The bonus feature on the Amazon version is worth watching to understand the difficulty caused by carrying 85 lbs of suit while acting.  The actors have to power the suits that are supposed to give humans a chance against an almost perfect killing machine. 

The script is exceptional for an effects driven thrill ride. This movie is a serious LOVE STORY where the object of affection dies every day no matter what Cage tries to do to save her. Watching that love grow is the part that is closest to Groundhog Day - although the affection Vera Farminga comes to feel for Jake in SOURCE CODE can also be considered despite Michelle Monhagen 

The J squad is another positive element - a clever counterweight to the stubborn General played by Brendan Gleeson and the Master Sergeant from Science Hill, KY by Bill Paxton. The General is almost as lethal to Humans as the Mimics. His stubborn refusal to consider Dr. Carter's insights into the aliens is just the kind of ego driven superiority - stupidity one might think possible in a General. (Think Patton or McArthur) The J Squad misfits are very entertaining and their humor adds excellent laugh-out-loud balance to the alien mayhem. 

OBLIVION was pretty dry and sterile compared to this invasion - The Aliens of Oblivion were clones of us - here they are a giant brain assisted by a few Alphas and few billion "Claws" or sinewy killing machines of lethal design using javelins of energy - *light and fire. These claws are fast & quick in every direction at once. Their movement is perfection and this will make one hell of an FPS video game. 

Still what I will remember is how Cage's love grows for Rita Rose the Angel of Verdun The drive to save the species is personified in the more difficult drive to save Rita AND the species even though she seems ambivalent to the concern.  As the credits roll we are left to imagine how Cage might fare in the new day of life without the Alien threat. Will he manage to finally win Rita's broken heart? That element of Groundhog Day is missing since Rita has no memory of Cage as the alien free day begins.    

Two "top reviewers" pan the film as Rotten. Two of dozens I've seen. I don't get their objections other than one seems to feel that the Alien should have used an EMP weapon to disable all human technology prior to invading. So I guess that reviewer should write his own screenplay. This one succeeds because the effects and stunt work are top notch against aliens that are 'new' in a crowded genre. The actors are well chosen and they fit their roles. But mainly because we can cheer for the humans through Cage's transformation into a man because he falls in love with an Angel - even one who is a "metal bitch"    Great Movie.

A sort of sci-fi Groundhog Day plays with elements we've already seen recently with Source Code, but manages to get all the important bits right that a lot of action fare tends not to deliver on. 

Those being solid action set pieces that don't feel too stagey or all-eggs-in-one basket-so-we-can-put-it-in-the-trailer, decent character arcs that actually have us root for our wouldbe heros and a script that's clever enough and funny in the right places.

Tom Cruise, annoyingly, shows us why he's still ranked amongst the A-listers but he's matched step for step by Emily Blunt who seems rather at home in an action setting. 

The actual plot narrative isn't the most inspired on wider view. It's still mankind vs. other save-the-world popcorn fodder, but Edge of Tomorrow provides plenty of thrills to keep you entertained and satisfied once the credits role.

I've always liked Tom Cruise. It seems like there is still a decent amount of people who don't but hey, we all make mistakes right? For Cruise hes' had Oprah, Scientology, dating Nicole Kidman and Penelope Cruz (seriously, they are so overrated), Vanilla Sky, amongst other things that made him seem a little douchey but besides that, not much else really.

Edge of Tomorrow struck me as a mix of a few solid past Cruise movies; Minority Report and War of the Worlds. Throw in a little Groundhog Day and you get this movie. Now that doesn't seem like a very glowing review but this was actually a pretty good movie and a solid start to the summer movie season. The film follows Cruise as a military officer who gets screwed by a high ranking general (A Crotchety Brendan Gleeson) and busts him down to private and is going to be thrown out to the front lines to fight an alien race known as the Mimics. The mission goes wrong and Cruise gets killed, but before he gets killed, he is exposed to the blood and guts of one of the Mimics which gives him the ability to wake up and re-live that day over and over. They realize that is how the Mimics were able to win the battle because they in a sense could manipulate time and know what was going to happen before mankind did.

In comes Emily Blunt's Rita, a bad ass soldier who conveniently enough, went through the same situation Cruise is now going through and arranges for him to find her each day (A.K.A. keep dying!) so she can train him to become a better combat soldier and plan to try and find and destroy the OMEGA (duh duh duuuuuuuuuuuuuh) which controls the entire horde of Mimics.

This movie could have been a disaster because it's really hard to sell a story that involves you seeing the same sequence over and over again. Thankfully, director Doug Liman and the script writers craft a film that keeps resetting but doesn't keep bogging you down in every little detail. They also don't go overboard with the sci-fi alien back story and details of the mimics and how to destroy them. They give you just enough to stay interested and supplement that detail with some kick ass action sequences. The beach battle is a treat to watch over and over because it makes you think of a "storming the beaches of Normandy" (it is in France after all) type scenario and also pays homage to Saving Private Ryan in a way. It's also pretty cool do see how well they have the characters remember and plan every little detail of a sequence that they have lived through before in order to keep advancing. This goes from big scenes like the beach battle to a scene where they are just walking down a crowded hall way.

What has made Tom Cruise fun to watch in the past 5 years or so is that fact that he doesn't seem to take himself as seriously as others might think. He isn't afraid to show his comedic side and play the not so traditional "action hero" in this movie and it pays off well. He does the almost cowardly, klutzy, warrior well and it really carries the film. Besides Cruise, Blunt is a babe, and Bill Paxton is great as the ass hole Sergeant. In fact, Paxton was basically a grown up version of his character from "Aliens" which made it even better for me. 

You will see a little Elysium, Starship Troopers, Source Code, and even similarity to video games like Halo and Gears of War. It all adds up to a much better experience then I originally expected which is perfect because that perfectly describes Tom Cruises' career of the past 5 years.
