If you are looking for an example of a movie that is unfairly criticized, look no further than Oblivion. That movie starred Tom Cruise. I would have bet that his latest movie, Edge of Tomorrow, would have had a similar fate. I would have lost that bet. Surprisingly, Edge of Tomorrow has some pretty outstanding Rotten Tomatoes and Flixster scores, but are they deserved?

Edge of Tomorrow has frequently been labeled as "Groundhog Day meets [insert action movie]." For the most part that's accurate. Two examples that come to mind are "Groundhog Day meets Die Hard" and "Groundhog Day meets Starship Troopers." The Die Hard comparison doesn't make much sense to me, except for the fact that Die Hard and Edge of Tomorrow are both action films. The Starship Troopers reference makes more sense since it's a sci-fi action movie about asshole aliens trying to kill us, and so is Edge of Tomorrow. And the aliens look and function somewhat similarly. If I were to be equally uncreative and come up with my own analogy, I'd say it's "Groundhog Day meets A Few Good Men meets Mission: Impossible."

So why all these comparisons to Groundhog Day? If you've seen Groundhog Day, you know that Bill Murray gets caught in some kind of time loop where he keeps living the same day over and over. In Edge of Tomorrow, Tom Cruise gets caught in a similar kind of loop. That is the reason for the comparison and it's an appropriate comparison to make. Other than this similarity, however, Edge of Tomorrow and Groundhog Day have little in common. One is a comedy and one is an action movie. One more thing they do have in common, though, is that they are both very good.

Groundhog Day was not universally lauded by critics when it was first released. Over time, however, several critics have gone back and "re-reviewed" it much more positively. It now has a Rotten Tomatoes score of 97%, but that wasn't always the case. Unforeseen by me, Edge of Tomorrow has received very positive reviews right out of the gate. Don't get me wrong, this film deserves a good amount of praise, I'm just confused why so many critics laud a good film like Edge of Tomorrow, yet tear apart a good film like Oblivion.

A lot of critics criticized Oblivion for being unoriginal. They said it was just a combination of stuff from other movies. Those same critics say Edge of Tomorrow is "Groundhog Day meets Die Hard," which is another way to say it's a combination of stuff from other movies. Yes, it is a combination, and like Oblivion, things are combined very well.

There are a lot of Tom Cruise haters out there. Yes he's probably nuts, but he also is a good actor, so get over it already. I thought that some of the criticism over Oblivion was due to the Tom Cruise hate factor. Maybe I was wrong, or maybe critics are as inconsistent as gravity is consistent. In any event, the lot of critics and audiences seem to really like Edge of Tomorrow, and they should. It's very entertaining. It's fun. It's even humorous at times.

In Edge of Tomorrow, Tom Cruise plays Major William Cage, who is not actually a soldier but instead is more of the the public relations guy for the military. He ends up in combat, however, and since he's not a soldier he doesn't fare too well. He dies, but he gets caught in the aforementioned time loop. Each time he dies, the day resets. He is the only one who is aware of this, and he is the only one who can learn from each passing day. At the start of the film, he wears the uniform but is not a soldier and he doesn't exactly have honor. He's a lot like Lieutenant Daniel Kaffee in A Few Good Men. By dying over and over, however, he is able to go through a lot of training and anticipate the actions of his enemies, which turns him into a pretty badass soldier. In Mission: Impossible, Tom Cruise plays Ethan Hunt, who is kind of like a badass soldier. This is why earlier I said you could describe this film as "Groundhog Day meets A Few Good Men meets Mission: Impossible." I've heard some rumblings from Cruise haters that he is once again playing his usual role in this film. First, if that was true, who cares? Second, it's not really accurate because he's definitely not the hero at the start of the film. He actually goes from one Tom Cruise character in the beginning (Daniel Kaffee) to another by the end (Ethan Hunt). If you've seen both of those movies, you know that those characters aren't the same. In other words, he actually has a nice character arc in this film.

This movie definitely has a nonlinear storyline. Some people say nonlinear storylines exist only to cover up an otherwise inadequate story. There is a name for these people... buzzkills. Personally I enjoy nonlinear stories quite a bit, when done well, and Edge of Tomorrow is certainly done well. When you are constantly jumping back and forth as much as this movie does, there are a number of ways things can go wrong, but they never do in this movie. It is cut very well and it is easy to follow. Another nice touch is that even though we see the same day several times, it is evident that we do not see each day Cage has endured. It is clear that he has had to repeat this same day many more times than what we get to witness.

Edge of Tomorrow has solid acting, great visuals and great pacing. It would take a lot of effort to be bored at any point in this movie. As far as the acting goes, there are really only four actors in this movie: Tom Cruise, Emily Blunt, Brenden Gleeson and Bill Paxton. Everyone else has incredibly small roles. This film is totally centered around Cage, and if I were to put a conservative number on it, he's probably present for 95% of the scenes. Cruise does a very nice job in this film. Emily Blunt does a fine job too, I think. Emily Blunt is just too damn fine for me to be objective. Okay fine, I can. She also does a nice job. One review I read said she was too intense like Linda Hamilton in Terminator. I don't agree with that at all. I love (some of) the Terminator films. And I would agree that at times, Hamilton was a little too intense. I didn't get that same feeling from Blunt in Edge of Tomorrow. She seemed legitimately tough, but her intensity was not overboard. Other than those two, Brenden Gleeson and Bill Paxton play typical roles for them, but they play them well.

One thing that surprised me was the humor in this movie. It's a nice and unexpected touch. It's dark comedy, of which I'm not usually a fan, but it is done well in this film. And because you know Cage is going to repeat the day anyway, you don't feel so bad for laughing at some of his misfortunes. I was surprised that there was any humor at all in this film, but after seeing it I'm very glad it was in there. It adds to the entertainment value, and it never detracts from the seriousness of the film, which is why it works well.

So should you see Edge of Tomorrow? Absolutely. It gets pretty much everything right. My only precaution would be this: It's unusual for an action film to get this many positive reviews, which could cause someone to have expectations that are a little too high. This is not the best movie of the year. But it is easily one of the best movies of the year so far, and that same statement will probably hold true come December. On a slightly different note, how the hell does Tom Cruise not age? Does he look any different today than he did 5 years ago? Or 10 years ago? You win this round, Scientology...

I REALLY wanted to like "Edge of Tomorrow." I didn't have a problem with the acting, the action sequences, the directing, or even the time travel stuff. My biggest complaint is the writing and the characters. 

"Edge of Tomorrow" fails to connect the dots for the audience. It drops the viewer into the film, and expects everyone to pick it right up and follow. There's no "show don't tell" going on. It trips over its own feet, and it's FRUSTRATING!

In order for a film to connect to an audience, the viewer must feel connect to the characters involved in the story. "Edge of Tomorrow" completely drops the ball on this. There's hardly an introduction to Cruise's character, and the audience is asked to follow him through the film. Moreover, the rest of the cast (including Emily Blunt's Rita) are merely game pieces in this video game of a movie. 

It may have been just me, but what's up with the camera work and lighting? In most of the action scenes, I can barely tell what I'm looking at, and in a lot of sequences I can't tell what's happening because I can't see a damned thing! LIGHT YOUR MOVIE SO THAT'S IT'S WATCHABLE! 

Finally, the writers did a poor job at tying up the loose ends. It felt like they were really rushing to piece everything together. That's never...NEVER going to work if you've already tangled up your film in time travel and plot twists. 

I wouldn't recommend watching "Edge of Tomorrow."  1 and a half stars.

A futuristic joy ride for those who can envision this "what if" war. As long as one doesn't dig deep into the logic of the movie, it is an entertaining spectacle.

Thankfully movies like "Edge of Tomorrow" still exist. The film is based upon a Japanese novel called "All You Need is Kill" by Hiroshi Sakurazaka, but it has no superheroes, it isn't a sequel and it isn't based upon any characters previously portrayed in film. Its idea may not be completely original but its tactics and portrayals lead to a completely entertaining trip to the movies.

In a not too distant future an alien race called `The Mimics' are quickly taking over large populations of Earth. Major William Cage (Cruise), a spokesman for the United Defense Forces, is not a military man, but that doesn't stop General Brigham from ordering him to take up arms and join the front lines of the battle to take back France; a sort of D-Day reboot with Aliens.

"Edge of Tomorrow" uses the same storytelling method as "Groundhog's Day", "Looper" or "Source Code" and surprisingly brought some of that "Groundhog's Day" humor along for the ride. Major Cage is a fish out of water as he is suited up in the high-tech exo-skeleton battle armor and the creators use the time looping moments to successfully hilarious moments.

Bottom line, Tom Cruise makes great movies and "Edge of Tomorrow" is no exception. It is everything that is great about summer blockbusters and it is everything that has been forgotten about cinema in general. There once was a time when you weren't so certain about the fate of the characters in your movie, full-well knowing that they are either invincible or planned for the sequel. There once was a time when action movies made you actually feel something other than, "Eww, that was cool." And it does that as well.

"Edge of Tomorrow" is a must see for every reason possible. You care about Cruise's Major Cage and you care even more about Emily Blunt's Rita Vrataski (Angel of Verdum). The movie uses the wide possibilities of film and entertainment to the fullest, never letting up and knowing when to be serious and when to have fun with its premise. This is the kind of movie that we need more of and less of the special effects heavy movies that make you feel absolutely nothing. Finally, somebody managed to combine special effects and awesomeness with emotion, humor and meaningfulness.
The final action scenes are long drawn out, but the rest of the movie is a riot and full of humor. Tom Cruise does a great job going from a pathetic fully green coward to a hardened killing machine.

Another solidly thrilling and compelling Tom Cruise science-fiction, action film. Terrific direction from Doug Liman, who also made the excellent Bourne: Ultimatum, and incredibly adept acting from Cruise and Emily Blunt. Edge of Tomorrow surprised me a bit even with my already heightened expectations, and it took me almost completely by storm. Cruise was thoroughly convincing as a cowardly military delegate without real combat experience, and, as the film progressed, equally as convincing as a battle hardened warrior who had experienced a brutal death hundreds of times over. The action sequences are technically astounding and often beautifully shot with sharp choreography and excellent special effects that blend almost seamlessly with the real world. I was genuinely intrigued by the Matrix Sentinel-esque creatures known as Mimics, and by their strange existence. They are animated very well and the way that they move is shocking. It's almost as if they are hyper stylized blood cells with a viciously awesome ability to destroy their enemies - their disease. Unfortunately for Tom and Emily, that disease is mankind. I had forgotten that Bill Paxton was in the film, so seeing him was a pleasant surprise and he was a welcome face. At only seven years Tom's senior, Paxton was able to portray a convincing, much older, hardened Kentucky born and raised hard-ass career military man leading his band of squadrons against the alien invasion. It was exciting. The supporting cast were all pretty fantastic as well. I found the story to be very compelling about twenty minutes in and that momentum never faltered - even up unto the final sequence. The final shot was absolutely perfect. I have always been a fan of Tom Cruise, and I am a die-hard fan of the science fiction genre in general - especially films dealing with extraterrestrials in any aspect. The Edge of Tomorrow was incredible. I would definitely recommend it without a thought - and I'll be sharing this asap.

A mind-blowing, adrenaline-pumping sci-fi action, Edge of Tomorrow is not only an example of what a summer blockbuster should be like, but also probably the best summer blockbuster of 2014. Inventive, fast-paced with glimpses of dark humor and self-irony, this is the perfect combination of breath-taking sci-fi action, alien invasion and surprisingly good Tom Cruise.  With all necessary ingredients for a full-throttle entertainment, Edge of Tomorrow is the most compelling and entertaining summer 2014 delivery so far.

In the near future, an alien invasion which started in Europe is threatening to annihilate mankind. A former PR and media relations professional and now a Major, William Cage (Tom Cruise) is thrown into battle despite the fact that he has never seen one. Killed shortly after the doomed invasion of his squad, Cage finds himself thrown back to the past in a sort of time-loop continuum which activates every time he gets killed. Soon, after finding an explanation for his state, he teams up with the special ops warrior Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt) to improve his skills and to prevent the inevitable defeat of the human invasion into the alien-controlled Europe.  Each killing of Major Cage reveals a new part of the mystery surrounding the aliens and is a step forward towards the defeat of the enemy.

Some might think that the time-loop repetition of scenes would slow down the movie, but on the contrary Edge of Tomorrow stuns with extremely tight pacing,  skillful tension building by director Doug Liman ever-evolving story that captivates the complete attention of the audience.  Add up the unexpectedly darkly comedic elements and surprisingly fresh performances by the two leading actors and you would get a complete summer blockbuster delight. Speaking of the actors, Emily Blunt is at top-notch level as the ass-kickin Rita Vrataski. However, it should be pointed out that Tom Cruise is the big star of the movie and shockingly to many (including me and other non-fans of Cruise) he delivers a formidable performance. Far from being a likeable character, his performance is lacking the typical Cruise-self-assured-ultra-cool-I-can-to-everything image. Major Cage is arrogant, egoistic, scared at some moments. Slowly and thanks to his work with Blunt, Cruises' character grows and gives him a chance to show that he could actually be an excellent actor (even the anti-Cruise fan should admit this when it comes to this movie).

To me, and probably to many others, Edge of Tomorrow would be the best 2014 summer blockbuster. To few (including me) this movie becomes an immediate all-time classic, due to its story, entertainment and sci-fi value, as well as formidable acting. A must see, Edge of Tomorrow is an absolute sci-fi delight and it finds its spot in my "favorite movies" list.

Edge of Tomorrow was the first film I watched in the aftermath of Transformers: Age of Extinction. If you know me well, you would know that I really did not like Transformers: Age of Extinction. I'm not the one to shit on movies, but I just thought it was bland, devoid of creativity, had crappy characters, watered down special effects, and next to no emotion or story. It was summer entertainment at its loudest and dumbest, and I don't mean that in a good way. Edge of Tomorrow was everything that Transformers 4 wasn't. It had heart, intense action, great characters, a cool premise, and a story that was chalked full of great humor and heart. Perhaps what really grabbed my attention was just how similar the setup was to Resistance:Fall of Man, which is a video game I happen to be a big fan of. If you're looking for a summer blockbuster that delivers all the thrills and laughs without dumbing it down, then look no further. Edge of Tomorrow is a pristine example of just how good summer movies can get. I like big dumb fun action movies as much as the next guy, but nothing beats a well told, heartfelt story... with mech suits and nasty-ass aliens.

Swanner:           The epic action of "Edge of Tomorrow" unfolds in a near future in which an alien race has hit the Earth in an unrelenting assault, unbeatable by any military unit in the world. Major William Cage (Tom Cruise) is an officer who has never seen a day of combat when he is unceremoniously dropped into what amounts to a suicide mission. Killed within minutes, Cage now finds himself inexplicably thrown into a time loop-forcing him to live out the same brutal combat over and over, fighting and dying again...and again. I borrowed the description from the studio because it explains this crazy plot better than I could.
 
Judd:                I went into this film dreading the experience. Tom Cruise and time travel? Kill me. I hate time travel movies because they generally require too much suspension of disbelief. I hate Tom Cruise movies because he always plays the same smarmy super solider. Edge of Tomorrow, however, hooked me within the first 10 minutes. First, the time travel gimmick is easy to swallow - easier than similar movies like Source Code. Second, Cruise is not the same grating character he always plays. This time around he's noob nobody likes and everyone expect to immediately die. In essence, Edge of Tomorrow is a movie that stars Tom Cruise, it is not a Tom Cruise Movie.
 
Swanner:           That's a very good way to say it. I was also pleasantly surprised that it wasn't the standard Tom Cruise character. I liked this one and he did a really good job with it. I think the script was the real star of the film, screenwriters Christopher McQuarrie (The Usual Suspects) Jez Butterworth and John Henry Butterworth (Fair Game) created a fast pace action picture that had me hooked as well. Movies like Groundhog's Day may work but they always induce eye rolling and watch checking where here I was never distracted or bored.
 
Judd:                The humor and the editing go a long way to make the movie watchable. As the story is unfolding, every time Cage dies it made a humorous moment. Because of the repetitiveness of the story, the screenwriters made very definitive decisions on what portions to show again as a foundation for the next part of the story. The lightning fast editing kept those choices fresh. Not once did I think to myself, "Ugh, we have to see this scene again?"
 
Swanner:           If there is anything to complain about it would be the sound. Don't get me wrong, the sound engineers did a great job it's the volume level was very high. I don't think it was a theatre thing, I think it was in the print. Other than that this is one of the best films of the year. I did want to give props to director Doug Liman. He's hit and miss with me. This time is definitely a hit!

The way they looked and moved was awesome, and I think they're going to rank up there with HR Giger's Alien.

The trailers were not impressive.
The Posters featuring just Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt in a Futuristic Armor didn't have the pizzazz.
And then, given the mighty roar that Godzilla made & and the slice 'n' dice X-Men showed, there was hardly any noise made for this movie.

But don't let that fool you - Director Doug Liman (The Bourne Ultimatum, The Bourne Identity) has directed an-Edge-of-your-Seat-Thriller!

Tom Cruise Emily Blunt Edge of Tomorrow

For one, 51 year old Tom Cruise gets to experience the following treatments:
1. He gets blown to smithereens.
2. He gets run over by a military truck
3. He gets shot in the head
4. He has a hole punched through his chest while protecting another soldier from enemy fire.
5. He is squashed by a helicopter falling from the sky.
6. He is torn apart by a glowing, tentacled alien.

And if that is not pleasing enough, there the rare sight of Tom Cruise - not as a Brave, Die Hard, Superhero - but as a sniveling, cowardly talking head who doesn't have the balls to be a man.
Tom Cruise Emily Blunt Edge of Tomorrow

Tom Cruise Emily Blunt Edge of Tomorrow

Edge of Tomorrow (based on a Japanese novel by Hiroshi Sakurazaka - All You Need Is Kill) is set in a near-future in which a methodical alien species dubbed "Mimics" has touched down in Germany and, over the course of five years, gradually overtaken most of Western Europe. The sole human victory over the invaders has been at Verdun-where a heroic soldier in a robotic exoskeleton, Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt (Looper, The Devil Wears Prada), single-handedly killed more than 100 Mimics and in the process became an icon of the resistance.

The story cuts to Cruise an Army major, a principal TV spokesman for the war effort, and an exceptional coward. But after an ill-considered run-in with a superior officer, he finds himself demoted, sent to the frontlines, and, soon enough, accidentally imbued with the peculiar ability to reset his day the moment he dies. The Story moves into an invasion that self-consciously recalls the Normandy Steven Spielberg envisioned in Saving Private Ryan. And then takes the form of Groundhog Day, Starship Troopers, and Source Code - all mixed into one movie.
Tom Cruise Emily Blunt Edge of Tomorrow

Tom Cruise Emily Blunt Edge of Tomorrow

Cruise finds himself repeating and repeating the same battle scenario, learning in painful increments how to fight death. The script twists around like its aliens and it's all visually arresting. Emily Blunt, who plays a tough commander is a nice exception to the customary damsel-in-distress narrative: this time out, it's Blunt who plays the battle-hardened vet.

What I loved best about this movie was the creative editing where every scene is shown in a different light, the repeated battles, ascending worlds, antiseptic violence, and yes, the unusual & understated chemistry between Tom Cruise and Blunt.

How come Emily Blunt wasn't the main star of this motion picture? She plays Rita, the badass soldier who's also known as "The Angel of Verdun" and "Full Metal Bitch." She was the most interesting character here and with nicknames like those who wouldn't be. Instead, we get Tom Cruise in a painfully by-the-numbers role. He's good playing the guy who keeps reliving his days Bill Murray-style, adapts to these repeated instances to hopefully attain victory, and falls in love with the dream woman. But Emily Blunt's Rita is no ordinary woman, she's the war hero whose mug is proudly plastered all over the military base and city. She is greatly admired and adored, winning respect and hearts (maybe that last part is just me). She takes no shit from no one. She is combat-ready, both physically and mentally. She wields a buster sword that looks like it belonged to Cloud Strife and wears a mechanical suit like the one Matt Damon wore in Elysium. She's just too bad. *slap*

Yeah yeah, blame the source material, but I'm serious: Emily Blunt is the star of the flick. Tom Cruise is a cowardly agent of chaos. He's stuck in a time loop and dies repeatedly (sometimes hilariously), but his character just goes through cliche after cliche, and much of the story is cliche except the enemy that are being fought against. They're an alien race called the Mimics whose only plan is to take over the world but there is a bit of creativity with these beings as the movie progresses.

Tom Cruise plays the coward Major Cage who is ordered to go on the frontlines by General Brigham, played to absolute stubbornness by Brendan Gleeson. Cage gets cold feet and tries talking his way out of it. He's unsuccessful but then, for some reason, he threatens to blackmail the general because... well, because then we wouldn't have a movie. What do you want? Something logical? When this exchange went on between the two I was already bent on hating this movie because of how badly written Tom Cruise's character is. That's the first thing we know about this guy and this is within the first five minutes of the movie. He's a coward trying to weasel his way out of the front lines only to rightfully get arrested, then be branded a deserter, stripped of his rank, and ordered to march with his fellow men to battle... or rather, their doom. How this guy became a Major who has no combat training whatsoever is beyond me. He doesn't have any experience, either. But I digress. If Lieutenant Gorman in Aliens who only did simulated jumps and managed to get that far, then I suppose it's not too far off for Cage to be a Major and also be a wimp.

They're going against a hostile alien force that look like a bunch of scribbles (you try describing them) and have been for a few years now, and now they're set to launch the largest military operation since the landing at Normandy (D-Day) 60 years ago--and by the way, real subtle with that symbolism, guys, and what makes it even more hokey is that this film's invasion just so happens to take place on those very same beaches in France. And critics accuse Steven Spielberg of being too sentimental. Tuh. Anyway, as fate would have it, we find out that this entire operation is doomed and will always be doomed. The demoted-to-Private Cage, after dying a few dozen times, begins to gain some momentum with his tactics after teaming up with Rita to find out a way to win this war. How they do this is rather creative because it all pertains to how/why Cage has this power of the reset button. Yeah, it makes for some funny death moments but it also doubles as character growth before getting to the real serious stuff that actually had me on the edge of my seat. Much of it was cliche but it brought up some fascinating and sometimes frustrating explication about the Mimics--one crucial moment had me scratching my head that I concluded it was just bad script writing.

Rita knows about Cage's reset button. Oh, I'm not spoiling anything. You see it in the trailer where she instructs Cage to find her when he wakes up before getting blown to smithereens (in another one, she kills Cage to reset events). How she knows this may bring up some paradoxical questions but it's fairly simple when the movie explains it. In fact, everything about this movie is simple--big budget features often don't allow its audience to think for themselves and instead half-bake their material. The filmmakers could've gone a bit deeper into the torments of Cage living and dying and seeing everyone die repeatedly, and they kinda did show this moment of crisis. It wasn't taken too far and was easily dismissed once the plot came back. I know it's just a movie but c'mon. His brain might overload since it's implied that this repetition goes into the hundreds. What person wouldn't go mad being stuck in an infinite time loop, repeating everything over and over again and seeing the same people die over and over again and he himself die over and over again? I remember reading an old comic book where a hero had the power to briefly rewind time to reverse a tragedy, and this hero resorted to drugs and drinking because she couldn't cope with these deaths despite saving those very lives.

Interestingly, there were times I began recalling Starship Troopers since this film has those propaganda posters featuring Rita plastered about, like the screenwriter wanted to satirize warfare or the soldiers of tomorrow or something. Even with the aliens here I got a Starship Troopers vibe. Alas, this movie doesn't remotely come close to being a satire. Edge of Tomorrow has these things but they're just... there, like they were all one big MacGuffin, including the aliens. Sometimes I felt the movie doesn't do anything with this stuff. At least the action and characters kept me invested.

Hollywood should consider bringing back female action stars, someone who can hold a candle to Sigourney Weaver or Jamie Lee Curtis. We really haven't had that these past few years aside from Jennifer Lawrence in The Hunger Games Saga. But we need someone who is determined and not just a ploy in politics, someone who is badass by nature. Rita was just that. This movie rocked because of her. I don't mind Cage once he gains traction (and again, some of his death scenes are hilarious) but I'd rather follow Rita, and the movie should have. The script could have done something with the whole war propaganda going on--it really makes me wonder the purpose other than hyping up the Rita character as the ultimate badass who needs a man in her life. I guess this was just male fantasy.

When we find out more about Rita, my question remains: why wasn't she the star of this feature? Again, blame the source material. It's not Cruise's fault. Like I said, he plays his part well but in a movie where a guy is stuck in an infinite time loop and befriends a woman, you know how it'll turn out. There always needs to be a romance. She's the prize of male fantasies though romance would be last on her bucket list. Rita is here, ready to lead her men into battle, whip Tom Cruise into shape (or kill him), and slash through hordes of aliens. That's not to say Cage is a spectator in this movie like how Kick-Ass was in both of his movies. He started off as a coward but he becomes the action hero we expected from Tom Cruise. He grows despite how formulaic this character development is. Our leads are great and some of the supporting cast is memorable, like Bill Paxton, and I wished we got to know more about J Squad other than looking like a bunch of misfits. Brendan Gleeson was also great in his stubbornness. But why nearly ruin a great character like Rita with all this fluff?

Both director Doug Liman and the author of the original Manga from which this movie is based on simply took influence from video game mechanics to replicate the video gaming experience... and I can see that. Players get pissed off and hit the reset button or load up a previous save because nothing is going as planned. That's the obvious with showing Cage respawing but how the movie captures the feeling, the mood, the atmosphere, and overall presentation of a gaming experience is damn good.

Story may be thin here but often I think the majority of gamers don't give a shit about story, not that we ever did in the first place (unless it was an RPG of some sort, or The Last of Us). Mario, a pudgy plumber, saves the princess from the evil King Koopa and has to fight turtles and goombas, and dodge Bullet Bills in the Mushroom Kingdom. We don't question the world or the enemies or the concept, it's just all there but not as MacGuffins like I criticized earlier. I dunno but it all just makes sense and we accept it. Unless someone fucks it up by attempting to explain everything like in that terrible Super Mario Bros. movie then it all falls apart. A lot of games, at least the older ones, didn't have much of a story and only gave us a simple goal: pass a level and advance. Sometimes you beat the game or you beat your high score (or someone else's). But you know the gaming experience, right? And this movie, daresay I, captures it perfectly.

At its simplest, the movie is just another Groundhog Day-esque type feature, and we already got one a few years back (the underrated Source Code, starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Michelle Monaghan) but Edge of Tomorrow provided good action, good fun (seeing Tom Cruise get killed in various ways), an unnecessary-but-acceptable romance, and an interesting invasion story with an interesting enemy. If it wasn't for Doug Liman and co. acknowledging the video game mechanics, I'd simply say the movie was okay.

Fuck it. I'm calling it one of the year's best movies, but it still fumbles quite a bit. It has potential but I still feel they were either prematurely dismissed or not given much consideration at all just to make things as straight-forward as possible despite having a complex plot point. Yes, it still feels like one big MacGuffin starting from the moment Cage threatened to blackmail his general (this includes the Mimics and that one thing I consider a plot hole). I wanted to know more about J Squad but the movie doesn't give much but thank goodness for Bill Paxton. The romance was unnecessary. And dammit, I want Emily Blunt to be the star! But goddammit if it doesn't perfectly capture the video game experience that makes me almost willing to waive my nitpicks because that is the movie's strongest suit next to Blunt's character. Edge of Tomorrow breaks from being labeled as an okay sci-fi/action romantic comedy, it's a great video game movie, the best since Scott Pilgrim vs. the World (2010). 

One final note: I'm a bit taken aback by the very last scene of this movie. As I'm thinking about it, I'm laughing like Donnie Darko. I guess that's all I can do.
It changes the original story quite a bit, but this makes for a more satisfying and more exciting edition that is better than the source material.

Al Filo del Mañana es una de las sorpresas más agradables y divertidas de este verano. Entretenida e inspirada, esta película dirigida por Doug Lima y protagonizada por Tom Cruise y Emily Blunt, esta basada en la novela japonesa "All You Need Is Kill" y nos narra la historia de un soldado desertor llamado William Cage, que es obligado a luchar en una guerra contra extraterrestres hostiles que quieren invadir el planeta, sin embargo, en el combate William Cage adquiere un curioso poder: repetir el mismo día una y otra vez. Aunque la premisa parecería repetitiva y una extraña mezcla entre Alíen, Halo y El Día de la Marmota, lo genial es que la historia funciona de maravilla. Esto gracias a la audaz dirección de Doug Lima, a sus editores y sobre todo al carisma de Tom Cruise (que hace lo que mejor sabe hacer), además de lograr una gran química con la hermosa y talentosa Emily Blunt.  De la misma manera los efectos visuales, la dirección de arte, el diseño de sonido y la partitura de Christophe Beck funcionan a la perfección, haciendo que el espectador se deje llevar por casi 2 horas y salir con una sonrisa. La cuarta aventura de Tom Cruise en la ciencia ficción es fresca, inteligente, divertida y sin pretensiones; un muy buen ejemplo de lo que las producciones veraniegas deben ser. A pesar de la mala fortuna que corrió durante su exhibición, tiene todos los elementos para convertirse en un clásico con el paso del tiempo. La recomiendo ampliamente, ¿no la has visto? ¿qué esperas? te pierdes de algo muy entretenido.

I personally enjoyed Edge of Tomorrow. Its pacing seems impeccable, riding the dialogue and action in a seamless effort to never lose the attention of the viewer, pulling the focus into the front seat and keeping them steadily but non-exhaustively anchored there till the end. 

The action is by no means "Transformers" style-- and by that I mean it's not over the top or pervasive to the point where interest is lost or you find yourself start to laugh at the pars of impossibility and unbelievability as they shatter. The action here is used with high value, intention, and with an entertainment value that comes close to that of such Marvel films as The Avengers. 

Tom Cruise has earned acclaim both from the controversies of his personal life regarding his Scientology beliefs, as well as his impressive efforts as a professional hollywood actor. His character, Officer Cage, is effective in every way you'd expect from Cruise. Starting out as the dubious, stuttering clown of an officer, to the transformed by the ways of war confidence of a soldier, Cruise is firm in the roots of who his character is and, does not for a moment, leave his believability untouched.

Emily Blunt flawlessly makes the relationship dynamic work as Cruise's female lead when she enters the story as the film's last missing piece. Blunt and Cruise work well together without a dull moment. There's either laughter or there's action, and when there's neither, there's effective drama. I can't recall a moment in the film where it's either not funny, not important, and not attention-grabbing. I felt this similarly with Amazing-Spiderman 2, where the dialogue leads to the action, and the action satisfies because it makes sense. When the action is done, the dialogue redirects with an intention, back to the action, and the action satisfies once again. This cycle repeats until the credits role. It's quite a feat to the director, actors, and editor, to piece together a movie balancing out humor and entertaining action scenes without there becoming a blurred line somewhere in-between. But here, the balance is applause-worthy, and so is seeing the film for a second or maybe third time. 

There are the side characters who help aid the humor from Cage and let it sail its sea. Brendan Gleesan portrays General Brighm as a stubborn, blunt general without an apology in the world. In contrast to the stuttering Cage in the opening scenes, this can be quite funny-- or very dry-- depending on your sense or humor and response to delivery. Bill Paxton's southern-sarcastic Master Sergeant Farell is a funny twist when placed with Cage as well, allowing their scenes to ride fluidly between action scenes. 

These dialogue scenes are by no means an unnecessary boring mix to the rest of the film. The humor in these dialogue-driven scenes does not feel dragged out. Editor James Herbert makes sure of that, cutting out any fat that may have been left behind in the takes on set. Whether director Doug Liman intentionally called "Cut" on set before the humor became awkward, or James' cuts are simply done perfectly, these scenes do not make the movie feel longer. In fact, they are eloquently timed and placed in such a fashion that the film makes sense, is not taken too seriously, and also allows the action scenes to be driven out in full without any restraint. 

Edge of tomorrow is rated PG-13 for intense sequences of sci-fi action and violence, language and brief suggestive material. The action scenes in this movie portray creatures (The "Alpha's", which are 100% CGI), that are violent, fast, and what they do might be disturbing for children to comprehend. Without giving too much away, there are moments, but one in particular, when a main character gets hit by something in combat, and what happens to them as a result is visually disturbing. Something like that out of The Rock (With Nicolas Cage and Sean Connery). There is one f-word expletive used but it is brief and somewhat cut off as the scene cuts at the last second. The suggestive material is nothing to really be concerned about, although children will get nothing out of it, it's nonetheless a sex joke that is not explicit or even crude, but simply funny. 

If there's anything to complain about, it's a minor detail. I couldn't help but notice the slogan, "Live. Die. Repeat." This directly describes in a very short paraphrase, what Scientology is about. So it's almost a joke on Cruise that he would star in a film practically selling his faith to the audience. Other than that minor hiccup, which is more of an annoyance or roll of the eyes than a film flaw, this film had me fairly impressed. 

Overall, I'd give Edge of Tomorrow a 4.5/5 stars.

Wow! Tom Cruise, disliked for all the wrong reasons, gives the naysayers to doubt themselves. This man can act. Cruise, the older he gets, the better  his performances get, and here I sit thinking he would never top 2004's Collateral, I've been proved wrong over and over.

Directed by Doug Liman, who kickstarted the Bourne Franchise a long time ago, thrusts the same type of energy in this project.  The rapid cuts, the shaky cam, the similar protagonist to Bourne. The film adapted off a manga, named All You Need is Kill, which used to be the film's title, until changed to Edge of Tomorrow, takes place in the future, where extra terrestrials named mimics have taken over a chunk of the planet, near their plans of world domination.

Tom Cruise as Major William Cage (Another name that will only exist in movies.) a soldier on the R&D side of fighting the war gets shoved into fighting on the field. Given no choice, he chooses to fight on the battlefield, and in doing so, he gains the ability to reset the day, the catch? In order to reset the day, he must die everyday. Yikes. 

The film follows William Cage's progression from a joke to an absolute beast. The cool editing makes that possible and adds a grand energy and comedic timing. One scene in particular is when Cage is being trained by Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), a badass seasoned soldier who used to have the ability to reset the day. 

The aliens need their power to reset the day back from Cage, as that's how the aliens were absolutely ravaging humanity. To stop that, Cage and Vrataski need to destroy the central hub. To give humans a chance and send the mimics packing.

The supporting cast includes Bill Paxton in one of his best roles to date, he legitimately seems to be having fun, and a stern Brendan Gleeson as a general, he fits that mold well too, Gleeson looks like a pretty stern person.

Shaky Cam is employed throughout most of the film, at the right times though, unlike Bourne Ultimatum, where even the conversations are shaking, there are however scenes in the film when characters speak are shot in handheld. Whereas the camera was shaking uncontrollably in Bourne, this is more of a quivering motion. So all is well. The dominant color schemes are Blue and Washed up Brown.  The interiors are blue and exteriors are brown, rightfully so, as most of the film takes place in a desert battlefield. 

Doug Liman makes all the right choices, editing wise, musically and scale.
There is no shortage of scale here, the film gets bigger with progression, it goes from desert, to the mountains all the way to the Louvre! It feels like a James Bond film mixed with Robocop. A true globetrotting adventure. Edge of Tomorrow, is the best film I have seen this year, and one of the best sci-fi adventures I have ever seen. Tom Cruise continues his awesome run of being an action here, after MI:4 and Jack Reacher. Emily Blunt  continues to amaze with her versatility and for Doug Liman, the Splinter Cell film sounds perfect as a follow up to this.

When the trailers for Edge of Tomorrow first appeared, they deceptively showcased a generic sci-fi blockbuster awash in a flood of similar fare with zippy names like Divergent or Transcendence. It didn't stand out. A friend quipped that someone should just invent a mech-suit so people don't have to keep making movies about them.

I could see where he was coming from - we've seen it all before in Elysium (2013), Avatar (2009), District 9 (2009), The Matrix Revolutions (2003) and even Aliens (1986). Meanwhile, what appeared to be a sci-fi D-Day scene caused my brother to dismiss the film as Saving Private Ryan (1998) with aliens. This is absolutely true; there's no coincidence that Edge of Tomorrow was released the week of the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings.

So it seems derivative, but it is surprisingly creative. It manages to bring the best of these elements together and successfully decant them into what is, after all, an original film. It's not a sequel to anything else, it's not part of a franchise, and that's always something to be happy about. It comes from director Doug Liman, who has directed many original action and sci-fi films, including The Bourne Identity (2002), Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005) and Jumper (2008).

As suggested, the conflict is evocative of the world wars (including both the D-Day landings and references to a decisive battle at Verdun) with a futuristic twist. An alien menace has decimated Europe and is poised to invade the United Kingdom, and we're thrown into the action on the eve of the last desperate attempt by NATO to push back into France.

Tom Cruise stars as Major William Cage, showing us once again that he still knows how to star in a blockbuster. Cage is not a real soldier; he's a PR man who thinks he's there to sell the war to the public. He begins with typical Cruise charm and confidence, which then shatters when he's sent to the front line by NATO commander General Brigham (Brendon Gleeson, the first we see of the film's solid supporting cast).

He ends up in a squad of oddballs (squadballs?) under Master Sergeant Farrell (Bill Paxton, who was in Aliens). Everyone has mech-suits, because it's the future and it's cool. Cage can barely operate his, and swiftly ends up on the receiving end of an alien mandible. The alien special effects are high quality; they are scary, inhuman and move smoothly but unpredictably.

But it's not all over, he's entered a time loop, which resets to the night before the battle each time Cage is killed in action, which he is, again and again. Ultimately, he is able to use this ability to turn the tide of the battle and the war by incrementally improving each day, both by developing his skills and finding out how to beat the aliens.

However, he couldn't do a thing without Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), who was doing the same thing until she lost the ability. She's a believably hardened veteran, and a hyper-competent warrior compared to the initially bumbling Cage. Though Cruise is the star, she takes the lead in the developing relationship between the two characters, even if he has to meet her for the first time every day.

The time loop inevitably draws comparisons further potential source material, in this case the classic Groundhog Day (1994). It's also evocative of playing a video game; loading from a previous save point and attempting to beat the same impossible level over and over.

The film plays off the natural humour created by such a scenario, but it is often very dark, as Cage must die each time to reset the loop. Yet the humour works well and is perfectly balanced with the action and desperation of the larger campaign.

Edge of Tomorrow is based on a popular Japanese novella called All You Need is Kill, and some of the aesthetics, including the mech-suits and Vrataski's impossibly huge sword evoke this origin. There's another nod when the incompetent Cage gets his suit's language stuck in Japanese.

Indeed, it is a global film, not just the American affair featuring Tom Cruise that it might have been. There are plenty of European actors, including Blunt, Gleeson and many of Cage's squad. The opening sets the scene quickly with a composite of BBC News footage, and the film is exclusively set in England and France, with deserted, destroyed and military occupied scenes of London and Paris among the most powerful.

Cage's character development is an excellent deconstruction of what we expect from Cruise as an actor. He starts out with a confidence built on cowardice, but is thrown completely out of his comfort zone. Over the rest of the film, the character works hard to attain a typical Tom Cruise level of action hero, which he doesn't attain until the climax.

In another summer of sequels, spinoffs, remakes and modern literary adaptations comes "Edge of Tomorrow", an original and immensely entertaining sci-fi flick that reassures Tom Cruise's status as one of the best and biggest action movie stars around. Yes, the movie's central premise is in a way a rehash of "Groundhog Day" and is based on the Japanese light novel "All You Need Is Kill" by Hiroshi Sakurazaka but there is no denying its original spin. In the wrong hands, the movie could have only hinged its central idea but Cruise as a man having to relive the same day over and over and getting to convince people around him is something to behold. There is also a surprisingly good amount of humor that Cruise thoroughly delivers thanks to a script written by Christopher McQuarrie ("The Usual Suspects") along with two others.

Set in the future where the world is facing an alien invasion from so-called "Mimics", Cruise stars as Major William Cage, a US army PR officer who gets to forcibly join a major battle on the beaches of France by a rough army general (Brendan Gleeson) using new Robocop-like suits that are believed to be the weapons against the aliens. The battle is lost before the troops even land but through a very unique alien encounter Cage gets to relive the last 24 hours of his life over and over again. While on the beach he meets Sergeant Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), a renowned soldier and hero and they try to work out a way to defeat the Mimics. 

The movie is big and loud in a good way and is a solid return to form for director Doug Liman ("The Bourne Identity").  It is also very well executed with solid visual effects (the beach battle sequence is reminiscent of the opening sequence in "Saving Private Ryan" in a good way. The chemistry between Cruise and Blunt is undeniable with Blunt like you have never seen her before as a hard-ass action goddess. The love story aspect is unexpected but works very well.  Gleeson is also good and so is Bill Paxton as a rough master sergeant who leads the platoon Cruise's character is assigned to. It is best to watch the movie with little knowledge of the details and see it unravel (the ads are wise enough to not reveal too much). The movie loses some momentum in its final act when all is said and done but it is still well worth the watch.

You haven't seen this film yet. I know because it's under-performing at the box office. This isn't the first time I've had to post this review but that's because you're stubborn. You won't believe me when I tell you how awesome this film is. You won't believe me when I tell you the advertising campaign did it no justice. You won't even care that it's virtually the only semi-original movie within this summer blockbuster season so far. You're still going to say you're tired of Tom Cruise and that EDGE OF TOMORROW just looks like an OBLIVION retread. No matter how many times or in how many ways I recommend EDGE OF TOMORROW you always refuse to believe the film is any good. But this time, please, bear with me while I tell you this story. It will sound ridiculous at first but the longer I talk the more rational it's going to appear...

In the year whatever a bunch of aliens called 'mimics' attack Earth, having invaded most of Europe. The U.S army's public relations officer, Major William Cage (Cruise), is summoned to London to join the front line on the beaches of France. Cage refuses, admitting quite smugly that he's merely a hack sales man good at putting a positive spin on the war but can't even stand the sight of blood let alone engage in battle. When Cage's attempt to blackmail the general that signs him up (Brendan Gleeson) doesn't go as expected he finds himself knocked out on a military base camp in London Heathrow the following day, demoted to 'private' rank and bossed about by a moustached sergeant (Bill Paxton). Shortly after, Cage does battle on a French beach where he and his squad are killed almost instantly only for Cage to awaken alive and well at Heathrow again... and then things get weird. Or more specifically, things get GROUNDHOG DAY. Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), the so-called 'Angel of Verdun' and poster child for the war due to her heroism in a previous mimic battle, is the only one that believes Cage and together they use his condition to their advantage to end the war.

Yes, at one point I was sick of him too. After leaving the theatre in tears on multiple occasions having watched this wonderful actor squander his talent on yet more sci-fi actiony nonsense I told myself I was done. Turns out Mr Cruise is a very hard person to stay mad at so I went into EDGE OF TOMORROW (whilst hating myself) with managed expectations and was pleasantly surprised. EDGE OF TOMORROW is nothing like its weak-ass marketing campaign would have you believe. For one thing, Tom Cruise's character is not a badass at all but an incompetent, cowardly little weasel who does everything he possibly can to get out of battle before he's dragged into it kicking and screaming. Yes, Cruise does ride a motorcycle at some point but that's not until much, much later after tons of character development. Speaking of which, part of the fun is witnessing Cage grow into a man who is courageous, strong and determined. And if all the heroic montages don't leave you rooting for Cage then at least you get to see Tom Cruise die a lot.

EDGE OF TOMORROW isn't a reboot, remake or sequel but is derivative of many sci-fi films like PACIFIC RIM and even video games like GEARS OF WAR and FALLOUT. Its premise alone pays homage to the movie I mentioned in my synopsis but it's the way the premise is handled that sadly the trailers don't get across: EDGE OF TOMORROW is hilarious. You'd think watching the main protagonist relive the same day over and over again would test my patience but the gag just never gets old. The complete and utter fail of Cage's first few attempts to sneak off and/or deal with the other soldiers or even just watching Rita shoot Cage when he gets severely crippled and/or compromised become increasingly hysterical and Cruise sells it with his excellent comic timing. Director Doug Liman (THE BOURNE IDENTITY) edits the loops in a way that serves the humour whilst making sure we don't grow as frustrated as the main character does. We get to see the cause and effect of Cage's actions in a non-linear fashion and there are sequences we, the audience, witness for the first time even though it's clear he has been through it several times already. Sometimes Cage gets so bored of repeating the same day he takes a break from the mission altogether and escapes to the pub! Liman milks this premise for all its worth and it's clear he's having a blast with it.

The battle sequences are well done as is expected from the director who kicked off THE BOURNE IDENTITY plus Cruise has always been excellent with his stunts. The biggest surprise where action is concerned actually comes from Emily Blunt. Not only is her character a badass but her being a badass within the context of the narrative is very realistic. You see this wee framed woman and you don't automatically think she could earn the title of 'Full Metal Bitch' (as she's called in the movie) but when you find out the real reason why it makes perfect sense. Blunt has great chemistry with Cruise and isn't just his arm candy like most of the women in his films are. 
On an aesthetic level, the movie feels very gritty and earthy to me in a lot of ways and part of that is from the familiar locational setting. As a Londoner, I must admit the River Thames making an appearance filled my heart with glee and I will now be looking out for tentacled monsters in the water each time I stroll down there.  But another reason why this universe felt so grounded was because it pretty much reflected the real world today in terms of technology. There were no clichéd holographic computers or transparent, electronic pieces of paper where the writing moves up and down as it's downloaded or any superfluous elements that typically don't serve a purpose other than to say it exists. This is a trap that a lot of sci-fi flicks fall into.  The only advanced technology in EDGE OF TOMORROW is simply developed in direct response to the alien invasion and that's the battle suits. I kind of loved that the suits seemed dumb and impractical initially but as Cage learns to use it better you realise how awesome the suits are.  The aliens also look great and I liked the sloppy and frenetic way in which they manoeuvred.

Once all the jokes are played out Liman relies on urgency and suspense to carry the last third of the movie.  The stakes rise tremendously and there's a general feeling of dread that makes you realise you've been taking Cage's new found power for granted up until this point. Unfortunately, this brings me to my only problem with the movie: the ending. The conclusion is a disappointing Hollywood cop-out that ultimately doesn't make sense and just seems like a cynical ploy to leave room for sequels. Liman also gives into another Hollywood cliché with regards to where the main characters' relationship goes - which is fine but it's nonsensical considering who initiates it and at what particular time. Obviously, this is a time loop flick so there is a lot you'll have to just 'accept' otherwise the gaps in logic will eat away at you but yeah, these two things were the least forgiveable.

Thankfully, the 2 hours that come before is so good ultimately the ending shouldn't affect the overall enjoyment of the film too much. EDGE OF TOMORROW is a thrilling theatre going experience that fires on all cylinders and will take you on a ride of emotions throughout. It uses humour to play with the concept of time which is only made possible by the stellar performances from Cruise and Blunt and some clever editing that ensures the gimmick never wears out its welcome. Its sci-fi elements are well realised whilst being grounded and never heavy-handed. It is simply tragic that people won't see this film in cinema but I hope I've done a good job of convincing you (this time) before it's too late. Don't let a bad marketing campaign and an annoying celebrity personality cheat you out of seeing one of the best films of the summer.

Tom Cruise. Yes, Tom Cruise. Most filmgoers and the general public see him as a bat-shit Scientologist who uses L. Ron Hubbard's belief system to condone acts of craziness and manifest destiny. But, the man, after nearly four decades in the business, is still a credible actor and more than holds his own in the genre (sci-fi) that has recently re-ignited his career. After a slew of misfires in recent years (Ghost Protocol notwithstanding), Cruise finally lands himself a juicy, comedic and fairly inspired part and premise that gets a lot of traction out of an unexpected adventure and cool gimmick. Set in a near future where countries have been lumped into factions and we are on the losing side of an uphill battle against creatures that hold the power to anticipate our moves on the battlefield and can reset time to influence the outcome of the war in their favor, Cruise's character is a Major, stripped of his rank at the last minute who joins a motley band of Privates at a drop-zone every day to die and repeat the process until he can get far enough to possibly win. This set up makes for some rousing set pieces, bits of humor and winks and nods to other sci-fi films of yore, as well as some great chemistry between Cruise and his leading lady Blunt who exudes sexiness and rapid-fire delivery in every scene. Turns from Bill Paxton as a nutjob Master Sergeant who finds himself perplexed at Cruise's in-depth knowledge of the operation after only seemingly meeting him one time (when in Cruise's reality 300 + times), he chews scenes. Doug Liman, as director, hasn't had this strong of a showing since The Bourne Identity and he infuses the film with an exciting and witty pace. However, toward film's end, it gets a little cumbersome and you can tell the gimmick has warn out its welcome. Still, at least the first 3 acts are a dizzyingly awesome ride that is well-worth the price of admission. Check it out :)

Edge of Tomorrow is a fine return to form for Tom Cruise that after a few lacking efforts, manages to deliver one of his strongest and best performances in the last few years. What stands out about the film is the story, which is finely crafted, exciting, captivating and memorable. Add to that a solid cast of actors that elevate the film's ideas, and you have of the most exciting action packed thrill rides in the last few years. Edge of Tomorrow is a thrilling, action packed picture, one that will grab your attention from the first frame onwards. Tom Cruise is a great choice to play the lead character, and what makes the film really worth your time is the fact that it uses a fairly simple concept, but due to its strong performances, and immaculate direction, Edge of Tomorrow is one of the finest genre films that I have seen in quite some time. The film is action packed, never dull or tedious, and with a well crafted story and futuresque vibe the film possesses, this picture succeeds on many levels as a brilliant piece of entertainment, and above all, it features Tom Cruise in a fine role that feels like it was tailored for him, and it's hard to imagine anyone else in the role. I felt that Edge of Tomorrow was one of 2014's finest action films, and with director Doug Liman who previously helmed The Bourne Identity, I have to say this is his best work since that film. He's made other films of course, but none have had the power of really grabbing your attention like the first Bourne film. Until now. With a fine blend of action and Science Fiction, Edge of Tomorrow is a memorable and constantly thrilling piece of cinema that is a must watch for anyone looking for top notch thrills. I highly recommend this film, and if you enjoy films such as District 9 and Elysium, you're surely going to enjoy this film. Edge of Tomorrow is one of 2014's very best action films.

As I'm watching this storyline unfold in an unconventional manner -- as the viewer's standard perception of time is toyed with like Silly Putty, initially unbeknown to them; enticing them to think and figure out what the fuck just happened... and keeps happening -- I find myself successfully submerged into the main character's experience, keeping me puzzled and amazed. I'm also provided a seemingly well calculated dosage of information and imagery that the director clearly lays out in a meticulous manner so I can do my own analysis and problem solving. This film actually empowers and stimulates my thought process, in a similar way that playing a challenging video game or developing a piece of software does. Aside from mind-blown, I'm left intellectually and creatively aroused. I actually end up with some ideas needing clarification or verification after watching it the first time, motivating me to play the movie one more time. Part of what makes this film's climax so satisfying is the absence of that gross after-taste I get from most mainstream films, in which directors opt to sleazily spoon-feed their audience since we're not intelligent enough to wonder, think, analyze, and make our own subtle conclusions.

Unique, original and tremendously exciting, "Edge of Tomorrow" is one of the best science-fiction films I've seen in a long time. Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt deliver electric performances to breathe fresh life into a genre that's become rather predictable over the last decade. With a witty script, intelligent ideas and smart action sequences, could a science-fiction film get any better? It's a towering achievement, a film you won't be able to get out of your memory for days.

Hey again. If you'd like to see this review in blog format, with pictures and all sorts of fancy junk, you can check it out here: http://mps-marvelous-movie-reviews.blogspot.ie/2014/07/edge-of-tomorrow-review.html

Or you can read it here as always.

Edge of Tomorrow is the success story of this year's summer movie season, and perhaps the year in cinema. Opening in competition with hotly-anticipated cancer-flick The Fault in Our Stars, and following up box-office behemoths like Captain America: The Winter Soldier and X-Men: Days of Future Past, it appeared as though Edge of Tomorrow was all set for martyrdom and eventual cult status. Strong word of mouth, however, gave the film great legs at box office, and has gone on to become one of the highest-grossing films of the year. That might be one of the most profound votes of confidence in the movie-going public we've seen in years. What's that you say? Transformers 4 opened with $100 million in America alone? Well, never mind, then...

All negativity aside, Edge of Tomorrow is one of the most entertaining, original sci-fi films in years. And while the time-loop premise does beg comparisons to the smaller scale Source Code (which is superior), Edge of Tomorrow stands on it's own as an exhilarating, surprisingly smart sci-fi actioner. Praise has to be attributed to the tight, funny script by Christopher McQuarrie, Jez Butterworth and John-Henry Butterworth, and Doug Liman's fast-paced, punchy directorial style (he is an alumnus of the Bourne series, after all), but it really comes down to the huge charisma of Tom Cruise in the lead role, ably supported by a small but effective supporting cast.

Cruise plays Major William Cage, a marketing shill for the army who finds himself on the front line in the attack on an alien race that has seized most of central Europe. After a skirmish with an alien that leads to his death, Cage finds that he is waking up at the start of the day each time he dies. From here, Cage goes on a journey to discover just why this is happening, and whether it can be used to win the battle against the alien forces.

What Edge of Tomorrow crucially gets right is it's premise. A film about a soldier fighting the same battle over and over again has the capacity to be an obnoxious explosion-fest as many lazy cash cow franchises often are this time of year. Or worse, it could just bore it's audience to tears with a meandering, needlessly repetitive plot device. Luckily, director Doug Liman has storytelling talent enough to keep the film moving along at a smart pace, allowing enough room for character development among the generally well-executed action. While the film is guilty of sagging in it's opening stages, and again near the climax, the combined charms of stars Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt and the effective humour of it's fresh script keeps audiences engaged for it's 113 minute running time.

It's Cruise who continually shines throughout the film however. As Cage, he gets to embrace the kind of light-hearted performance he usually avoids (save for his show-stealing turn in Tropic Thunder). He keeps the audience invested even as the film drags through a few of the typical science fiction clichés we've come to expect of the genre. Emily Blunt, too, makes up for her disappointing performance in 2012's Looper. Her portrayal of Vrataski has a surprising depth, as the character is more well-written the usual female companion character. When the film occasionally switches to Vrataski's viewpoint, it allows Liman to toy knowingly with viewer expectations, and showcases Blunt's unexpected talent in action.

While the vocal fans of the film may mislead you, it does have a few glaring flaws, not the least of which is the lack of steam it has by it's end. As Cage repeats the day and battle again and again, Liman never seems to run short of interesting and often hilarious ways to present Cage and combat. However, when it comes time to wrap the film up, Liman resorts to some unfortunately standard action set pieces and little of the dynamic, zippy action from earlier in the film are to be found. The climax of the film itself leaves little impression, and lacks the same inventive touch of the rest of the film.

Aside from those flaws with the action, and a few pacing issues within that climax, Edge of Tomorrow lives up to the hype, as Doug Liman delivers an engaging blockbuster that trades off any truly memorable action in favour of a well-written, very well-acted sci-fi film with much more brains than it's contemporaries. While the box office results were lacking, and the film has a much better second act than a third, Edge of Tomorrow proves that there is life in original science fiction, and that Tom Cruise, at over 50 years of age, still has the chops to carry a film wearing a robotic battle suit.

Edge of Tomorrow gets a 9/10.

Edge Of Tomorrow is a completely derivative yet, actually pretty enjoyable Sci-Fi/Action flick starring Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt. The film is based on Hiroshi Sakurazaka's Manga All You Need Is Kill and tells the story of a not too distant future where an alien invasion force has landed and taken a strong foothold in Europe. The beings called 'mimics' seem to anticipate the united armed forces' every move until a victory in Verdun, France, led by Sergeant Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), gives the Earth a glimmer of hope that the enemy can be defeated. A U.S. military PR man Major William Cage (Tom Cruise) is brought in to sell the world... though not sure why the world would need to be 'sold' when the situation is so dire... on a massive armed attack on the beaches of France by covering the attack from the front-lines to which the cowardly Cage protests and even tries to blackmail his way out of. This gets him arrested and busted down to foot soldier to now to join the invasion in actual combat... where he is killed within minutes. But, Cage wakes up from death the morning before when first being sent to his new squad and relives the day till being killed again... only to awaken 24 hours earlier once more. With full memory of the previous days, he gets better and better at staying alive until he runs into Sgt. Vrataski who knows what's going on... it's happened to her too! His encounter with the blood of a special alien drone known as an 'Alpha' has given Cage the alien ability to re-set time and now teamed up with "The Angel Of Verdun" Cage must keep dying till the two successfully destroy the hidden alien power source and stop the enemy before all is lost. But, the re-set power is not permanent and one of Cage's deaths could be his last... if his own forces don't lock him and Vrataski up for being crazy first.

Sure this flick is a Groundhog Day, Starship Troopers, Battle: Los Angeles, and Aliens thrown in a blender with a bunch of other movies but, under Doug Liman's direction it's actually a lot of action-packed fun. The action is staged well and the film moves at a good, steady pace and really avoids becoming the mess it could have been with such a convoluted story. The SPFX are flawless and while the design of the film gives us little new, it is suspenseful and has enough of a sense of humor about itself to get past any familiarity. We also get some likable characters to become endeared to and they are well cast. Sure we may not like the cowardly Cage early on but, the more he grows as a soldier and a person the more we like him and are right there with him when he graduates to full blown hero. The time travel elements are also kept pretty basic and while there are always questions when time travel is concerned, Edge keeps the glaring problems to a minimum by not getting too over enthusiastic with it's use and while certain story elements will fold under too much scrutiny, the film moves fast enough to keep you from thinking too much about it. Liman also gives us some intensity but, keeps the tone of the film from getting too dark and the mix blends just right to keep things on an entertaining level. The script by Christopher McQuarrie and Jez and John-Henry Butterworth never gets too complicated and is smart enough to change up the formula about half way through to avoid predictability or monotony even though we still have a good idea how things will work out. The only real stand-out flaw is a an ending that is a little too neat and convenient in order to keep this flick a crowd-pleaser but, it's not bad enough to not go along with it or, seriously hurt the movie.

A big plus is a good cast that perfectly understand the material. Cruise has fun playing a sniveling coward for a while before transforming more into the action hero he is renown for. And once that happens he is as solid as always. Blunt is obviously enjoying being able to play such a badass but, one that doesn't loose her humanity or femininity. Vrataski is tough but, very likable and sexy and we certainly wouldn't mind a post battle celebration in her bunk after the war. We also have fan favorite Bill Paxton as a scenery chewing Southern Master Sergeant who leads Cruise's platoon of misfits into battle over and over and refuses to believe him when Cage has said he's done this before.... which leads to another small peeve, that in such a dire situation and despite how much foresight Cruise's Cage seems to have, no one ever gives him or Vrataski even the slightest benefit of the doubt that they can end the war and defeat the invaders. No matter how much info they seem to know, they are completely dismissed. True, it's a far fetched story but, the world is about to be lost you'd think someone would at least entertain their notions except for his oddball platoon, who are the ones least likely to believe him... especially when they have a physicist to back them up... but, even the physicist is cast aside despite his wealth of knowledge. Makes no sense.

But, despite it's flaws and being basically a mash-up of things we've already seen, Edge Of Tomorrow is an entertaining 113 minutes and was far more satisfying then expected. Go in not expecting much and you might actually come out surprised and having had a good time. A fun Summer movie.

Update:
[12/28/14] I stand by what I said in my original review (see above), however, I'm going to raise the 4-star rating to a 5-star rating. Here's why, "Edge of Tomorrow"--now marketed as "Live. Die. Repeat" (which is a WAY better title in my opinion)--really does make the respawn aspect work heavily in its favor. Rather than showing us each scene over and over again, the director chooses to omit some things and include others so that each revival feels different. For instance, when Tom Cruise's unit comes looking for him and Tom's character says "not today, guys." It's clear that this segment has happened many, many times before--we, the audience, have simply never seen it until this point. Another example would be when Cruise and Emily Blunt confront General Brigham, which they'd done on many attempts [even Tom tells the general that they've met before]--yes, Cruise's acting is excellent--but there's also a part in that scene where Tom admits that he and Blunt have never gone that far. That sort of "have they done this before or not" works amazingly, far more than I gave it credit for in my first viewing of the film. I'll just add that I bought this on Black Friday last month for $7.99 on Blu-Ray--I'm very happy about that.

Tom Cruise returns to old form

Let's be honest, Tom Cruise's last entertaining part was in 2008's "Tropic Thunder" as Les Grossman.  The young man, who introduced himself to us in the 1980s with films like "Taps" and "Risky Business", has grown up right before our eyes, both physically and professionally.  By 1986, he reached the highest watermark any Hollywood movie star could aspire to, flying F-14 Tomcats in the mega-blockbuster hit "Top Gun".  As an established box office sensation, Cruise then cemented himself to dramatic roles in such films as "Rain Man," "Born on the Fourth of July" and "A Few Good Men"-diversifying his acting portfolio with meatier leading roles.  

It wasn't until the inaugural "Mission: Impossible" film in 1996, that Cruise really began to jump at the opportunity to play action-packed heroes in Hollywood, perhaps attempting to become the next Arnold Schwarzenegger.  The "Mission: Impossible" franchise forever linked Cruise to action movies, effortlessly discarding his many other acting talents to the side in a heaping ball of flames.

The truth is that Cruise is too good of an actor for directors to hide his theatric skills in action-packed thrillers.  Cruise's best films are when he's the most vulnerable with a compelling story to tell.  His efforts in "Magnolia", "Jerry Maguire" or "The Last Samurai" all prove that.  But his lackadaisical "Collateral" (2004) and "War of the Worlds" (2005) played like mid-life crisis films, desperate productions that only highlighted Cruise's pigeonholed genre of mindless action thrillers.   

In "Edge of Tomorrow", Cruise regains his lost film mojo and delivers his best leading actor performance in over a decade.  He plays Major William Cage, a public affairs desk warrior assigned to the front lines to fight an alien species.  Costarring, and perhaps most responsible for Cruise's outstanding work in this film, is the talented and well-cast Emily Blunt as Cruise's Special Forces sidekick.  Together, they make a formidable force in this sci-fi thriller-with Blunt easily the deadlier of the two.
Director Doug Liman ("Swingers", 1996) creates a time loop saga that will have audiences making the easy comparison to "Groundhog Day" (1993) for its repeated reliving of the day's events over and over.  Likewise, "Edge of Tomorrow" garners quick resemblance to the alien battles in 1997's "Starship Troopers", with the fate of the planet resting on the outcome of the war.  Liman's "Edge of Tomorrow" narrowly avoids replaying the opening scene one too many times.  It's obvious that all his efforts in the film were focused on these repeated, yet compelling, time shenanigans versus developing a thoughtful movie conclusion.

The good acting in "Edge of Tomorrow" by Cruise and Blunt overcomes a weak script and an anticlimactic finish.  In fact, the relationship between Cruise and Blunt holds this film together long enough for viewers to give it a solid grade and come away satisfied.  The first hour of the movie is fascinating with the use of the time loop and affords Cruise many opportunities to appear vulnerable, weak and timid...showcasing several layers to his evolving character.  The second half of the film, unfortunately, dissolves into a less thought-out finale prompted by a lack of investment and caring from moviegoers into the outcome of the battle.  Once the time loop is closed and Cruise's work over with Blunt's deadly Rita Vrataski, viewers will be thankful the ordeal and film have concluded.  But not before realizing that the Tom Cruise of old is back.  And that's good news.
