"They say we're young and we don't know.  Won't find out unit-ii-l we grow."   This line of Sonny and Cher immediately takes me back to Bill Murray waking up over and over again in the classic "Groundhog Day".  Similarly the words "On your feet, maggot!" gouge themselves into your brain in Tom Cruise's latest blockbuster Edge of Tomorrow.  

Based on the novel "All you need is kill", which was the original shooting title of the film, Cruise plays a really interesting character - William Cage - who begins the film as a cowardly and conniving army media man before circumstances force him to progressively step up find the hero inside himself.   The Europe  of the not too distant future has been invaded by a bizarre alien life form - the Mimics:  a hive like being that breeds like rabbits and quickly overruns the whole of mainland Europe.  Clearly UKIP must have got into power by then and shut the Channel Tunnel, since the alien invaders have not yet conquered Britain which stands alone against the enemy.  

The infantry of the allied forces fight in well-armed mechanised suits, and Cage - much against his will - is strapped into one of these devices and 'parachuted' into the front line on the Normandy beaches:  It is rather ironic that I watched this film on the 70th anniversary of when our brave troops did the same thing.  

Why an aerial invasion would choose to land on the open beaches rather than some nice leafy field more inland is a question perhaps best not dwelt on, but it wouldn't make any difference anyway:  unfortunately, the Mimics can manipulate time and they already know the allied forces are coming, resulting in a massacre.   Cruise is killed and the film ends.  Or rather no, actually it doesn't.  From the result of a nice plot twist (no spoilers), Cruise reawakens at the start of the same day and can escape the death that befell him, at least for a little while longer.   And so it goes on living up for once to the movie's catchy tag-line - "Live, Die, Repeat".   As this proceeds, Cage appears, to his fellow comrades, to have almost God-like powers of combat through stunning demonstrations of intuition.  I was reminded again of what Bill Murray's Phil Connors says in "Groundhog Day":  "Well maybe the *real* God uses tricks, you know? Maybe he's not omnipotent. He's just been around so long he knows everything."    

Cage teams up with legendary fighter Rita, also known as the Angel of Verdun, played by the wonderful Emily Blunt.   Rita is the only person to believe in Cage's powers, the reason being (already unnecessarily pre-spoiled via the trailer) that she used to have the same power but lost it.  Together they must find a way to dual-handedly end the war.

This is a great, albeit not flawless, film.  Directed by Doug Limon, of the Bourne films, the pace is non-stop and the story infused with enough thrills, action and humour to thoroughly entertain over its running time, which (and a common complaint from this critic) is pleasingly under 2 hours.   Cruise is a star that drives Marmite-like love and hate reactions.   And so this is a film that has something for everyone:  for the lovers of the diminutive action figure, Cruise is in great form and revels in the chance to step up to what must have been a physically exhausting shoot.  For haters of the guy, they get to see him die on stage -  - repeatedly!   Emily Blunt also shines in her role, and the fledgling, almost reluctant, romance that builds between the two characters is well played.   All of the supporting cast, especially the assorted grizzled characters of Cage's J-troop, add variety and depth to the story.  

The special effects are first rate, with the evil Mimics appearing truly threatening as they emerge suddenly from hiding places under the ground:  something perhaps to bear in mind and pre-brief on if you have younger children you want to take.   

This is very nearly a five-Fad film, and I thoroughly enjoyed it.  As with any time-travel related film, there are some plot holes that appear when you pick under the skin of the story.  This is particularly true of Emily Blunt's character.  And the Hollywood ending of the film is rather unsatisfactory and not terribly logical in keeping with the excellence of the rest of the story.  But overall this is a film worth you catching at the cinema.  A thoroughly good night out.

You'd have to go all the way back to 2008 (Valkyrie) to find the last time I saw a Tom Cruise movie in the theater and this is only the third since 2004's Collateral.  It is safe to say: "I'm not a fan" but I also admit to liking a few of his films I deemed unworthy of seeing in a theater -- Oblivion and Jack Reacher to name a few.  Edge of Tomorrow is a Groundhog Day-esque sci-fi spectacle starring both him and Emily Blunt (The Devil Wears Prada) as soldiers who are facing off against a nearly unbeatable alien race that has implanted itself in European soil (literally) destroying most of the continent as it always knows mankind's every move.  A cowardly, unlike-able Cruise finds himself dropped anew on the beaches of a modern day D-Day where he is killed only to immediately awaken a day earlier ... which happens over and over again.  Blunt plays the lone person who believes his story.  Together they must figure out how to destroy the destructive menace to humanity.  Brendan Gleeson (Braveheart), Bill Paxton (Twister) and Jonas Armstrong (BBC's 'Robin Hood') all co-star.  The film is surprisingly fun and intelligent.  It also was nice seeing Tom Cruise eat some humble pie a time or too.  This is fun sci-fi that might have been a tad bit too long; but I still enjoyed it.

I'm just going to say it up front: This movie has been the most pleasant surprise of the year.

So this movie takes place in the near future where a race of aliens called the Mimics have invaded Earth, and we fight them using gun-loaded battle exoskeletons. Tom Cruise's character gets forced into battle, and when one alien's blood covers him, he repeats the day every time he dies.

The biggest comparison this movie gets is that it's a sci-fi version of Groundhog Day. However, it's actually closer to a lesser-known movie called 12:01, another movie where a guy repeats the day. I say this because, while Bill Murray's character repeats the day because of a magical and unexplainable reason, 12:01 and Edge of Tomorrow give scientific reasons that are in line with the context of their respective films. And without going into detail, they explain why this is happening pretty well.

For a movie about repeating the day, this movie hardly feels repetitive. They do a good job of skipping over what we've already seen in favor of the new things he tries, and there's even some times where we don't even see his first time trying something. This really helps in keeping this movie fresh and not tired throughout.

The other major character in this movie is Emily Blunt's character. She's a war hero from a previous battle, and we learn that she knows what Tom Cruise is going through because she also used to be able to repeat the day, so she helps him train and get better at battle. Like Cruise, she's awesome in this movie. She pretty much officially throws off her "I'm best known for looking like Katy Perry" label.

A big, loud action summer meant-to-be blockbuster hit that actually wasn't too bad. The movie takes place, of course, in a miserable futuristic world where the human race is at war with an alien species. It has some humor and the acting is convincing for the most part.  Charlotte Riley stands out because her acting and what I think was supposed to be a Southern accent were not convincing. I would have liked Rita to be a little more hardcore badass, but she was still a strong character.  Bill Paxton was so convincing I actually didn't realize he was in this movie until I saw the credits.  The special effects are fine but, as in Godzilla, much of the biggest scene goes on at night so it's in the dark - I don't know why the filmmakers have been going in that direction, it makes it hard to tell what is going on.  There is some use of what I call 'shaky-cam' at moments I don't understand why the director felt it would be beneficial to the film.  Overall, it was a mildly entertaining summer flick.

You might think that a cross between Elysium, Groundhog Day, and Starship Troopers would not be a good thing. You'd be wrong.

With an above average sci-fi premise, best-of-the-year film editing, and a smart, witty script, Edge of Tomorrow delivers a great time at the movies. It does not gasp at high concepts or emotional depth, but it has a consistently enticing air of adventure, fresh and snappy action, and enough brains to keep us interested and involved.

Although not a strong dramatic film, it does allow Tom Cruise to give one of the better performances of his career, and Emily Blunt to deliver what may be her breakout role as a leading action heroine. 

Doug Liman directs smoothly, so that you could almost forget how bad something like this might have become in the wrong hands. The tone is pitch perfect, and the timing and pacing could really not be better. 

Unfortunately, the marketing campaign for this movie has been very disappointing. IF like me, you  enjoy sci-fi, but saw the trailers and were not interested, I urge you to see it anyway...you will not be disappointed.

This is a film that may not be remembered in ten, or even five years, but it has my high recommendation to enjoy it here and now. You will have had the experience, and that's what matters...even if by tomorrow it never happened.

It's a known fact that Tom Cruise is an action movie star; anything he touches turns to gold and his niche is action movies. Once again, he proves this by providing a thrilling and exciting ride that you may want to take over and over again.  However, while it's a great action movie, it ends up coming up a bit short in some departments, especially the cop-out, hollywood ending (in my opinion) which makes it  a high-concept movie which is less than the sum of its parts.
	So in a nutshell, the earth has been at war between humans and aliens, which is not exactly the most original plot line. What is original is Cruise's character, Cage. He's a media representative. That's initially what got me; Cruise is usually introduced as the action movie's hero who saves the day, and granted he does this, it's the journey and transformation of Cage that really sunk its hooks into me. He's never seen a day of combat but on his first day, manages to kill one of the aliens, called 'mimics' as they can predict our every move as humans, but in the process dies. It's a bit daunting to see Cruise die so early in the movie and it really shakes things up. When he dies, he manages to inherit a power from the alien in which he can reset the day every time he dies.
	Now the resetting of the day plot device could have gotten annoying or repetitive, but the director manages to carry it out expertly. I don't want to spoil too much about the movie's plot but let's just say that the plot, though predictable, was still entertaining. He meets up with Rita (Emily Blunt. Lord.) and together they plan to save the world. Like I said, the plot has been done before, but it's how its carried out. Cage basically through trial and error tries to see how far he can make it via memorizing the various positions of the enemies and obstacles. This is one of the first few things that made me think of the movie as a video game adaptation, which only got more interesting as the movie progressed but i'll get to that later.
	The thing about it is, while the plot device is good, it removes a lot of tension from the first 3/4 of the movie as you just figure he's going to come back so he can rectify his mistakes and go even further. This, rather than provide tension, provided hilarity as there were a lot of funny ways that Cruise dies in the movie, and a lot of times Rita kills him just so they can reset. But throughout, the movie never becomes boring. It's an action spectacle; with the 3D really helping to pull the audience into the experience. The action scenes are tense and very well choreographed. To be honest, when I saw the first poster of Cruise in the "Exosuit", I almost laughed out loud. But he really pulled it off, Blunt too of course. They must have been at the gym for weeks to have worked with that thing on them for the majority of the movie.
	What was also amazing was Cage's character development; although he was a bit 2D because he had no real story or motivation, which was disappointing as Cruise has been known to play a man with loss very well, his evolution from scared, trepid media person to action hero by the 3/4 mark is very satisfying. Cruise nails everything once again, with emotions ranging from hopelessness to strength and weakness. He's just got this charm that sways the audience in whatever he's doing. Something of note that is that this is very unlike Cruise's normal character and it's almost as if he was poking fun at the audience's usual expectation of him when he says almost anything to get out of the combat situation. It's a nice reversal and  its come to help me appreciate more of Cruise's versatility as an actor.
	It wasn't all rainbows and sunshine though, as in a remarkable turn of events, Cage manages to get tired and upset that absolutely nothing he does can change the future after a while. It's an interesting emotion to insert into the character and added a dose of realism despite it's sci-fi background. Again, remnant of a video-gamer when you can't beat a boss or a dungeon no matter how hard you try and you reset from a save point and continuously try to change your fate. I don't know if the movie intended to do this, but even if it didn't, this was a very well placed and appreciated idea.
	Blunt's character however, suffers in terms of development, as this is mainly Cruise's movie. There's no real depth to her and thus, each time she dies, you feel no real remorse. I will give them this though; it was obvious that some sort of romance had to be sparked between the two good looking leads of the film, but they managed to put it on the back burner with only a few googly eyed looks here and there, and that was appreciated. I really would have hated to see them fall in love and all that with the fate of the planet at stake. Despite no development for her character, by the end of the movie you do feel for her though, even if a little bit, but that's because of Cruise's and Blunt's great chemistry.  Other characters; meh. They were all forgettable as they had no room  for them in the plot, except the occasional 'proving that i've relived this day' segment or in terms of humour, which is sad because the sacrifice would have been okay if they had developed Blunt's character because I really did want to like her, at least more than what they presented.
	Flaws are a few; plot for example; they never really explained how the aliens got the power, which in a way, I can't blame the movie for as I can't sit and think of a good explanation for an audience where they can understand and believe a realistic reason for how you can reset a day. I feel as if they did not give the Mimics enough backstory and just made them into a one dimensional villain; something for Cruise to aim to destroy. This is disappointing as it would have been interesting to find out more about their motives and why they wanted to take over earth in the first place. The plot device is also a bit flawed as I know that they were trying to show various different places at which were happening at the same time, but the time felt a bit lagged in that he was alive for longer than a day in some resets, and as such, had the chance to do more. Some of the physics was also not right and a bit unrealistic, especially at a crash scene near the end but I don't want to spoil. Let's just say that it was 'main character syndrome' that saved Cruise as no one else could have survived that.	
	All in all, Edge of Tomorrow does what it sets out to do; provide an entertaining action movie with tension (well for the final quarter) and impressive sequences. As an overall movie, I feel disappointed, but as an action movie, it's really great, showcasing yet another example of why Cruise is just so good at what he does. People may hate on him, but at the end of the day, you can't say that he isn't good at it. Interesting story and plot device, albeit with some loop holes, but enjoyable nonetheless. 8/10

Edge of Tomorrow is an action movie with a heart and brain if the highest order, and surprisingly so. I thought this film would be a decent foray into adapting Japanese literature, but it is something else entirely. It feels like a classic action film that has been around a few years but has only recently got the attention and affection it deserved. That is something that a lot of blockbuster filmmakers crave for: a film that cares about the story it's telling and making a memorable experience out of it.

Tom Cruise is not the typical 50+ year old you've seen in the movies before. He plays a character who feels and acts younger than any of the recent stuff he's been in. He is an inexperienced fighter terrified about the horrors of this war, where aliens are threatening to destroy the human race, and Cruise is forced to join the fight and kill the extraterrestrials on the shores of France. There he dies, but comes back to life to the moment before he joined the fight, and keeps living and dying in an endless cycle learning step by step and improving step by step so he can get out of the apocalyptic situation he is in.

Edge of Tomorrow is an original film that is like the kind of film you are hungry to watch again and again, just like playing a video game where you keep dying but keep playing, learning from yore mistakes and loving the game.

Is there anything bad about Edge of Tomorrow? Not really. It's all good, except the ending which I will not spoil, but it isn't all that bad in itself.

It definitely deserves its high score.

Video games turn us into gods. We die, we're reborn, and we die again--death's only meaning is monotony, the only loss a loss of progress. It's either a premonition of transhumanist conquering of death or else another in a long series of fantasies we tell ourselves about immortality to sleep at night. Either way, video games have conquered death. So have movies.

"Edge of Tomorrow" takes this conquering of death and uses it as its premise. Borrowing the conceit of "Groundhog Day" and planting it in a sci-fi thriller, "Edge of Tomorrow" uses many of that film's tricks, but, for all the similarities, it feels fresh rather than derivative--in a new context, with new characters and objectives, it's less the profound comic parable (though still very, very funny) and more a straight ahead adventure story, and in that regard it works like gangbusters. There isn't much profundity here--there are a couple of mostly superficial allusions to Christianity, and there's a nice weight given to the idea of only having one shot at something in a world (both theirs and ours) used to second chances, third chances, fourth chances, fifth chances, used to the reset button. Still, what sets "Edge of Tomorrow" apart is the precision, the concision and the cleverness of its script, one of Hollywood's best, most compact and entertaining yarns in years, Tom Cruise's phenomenal performance, in which he proves again he's one of the greats, giving a performance that's impressively complex and seemingly effortless, juggling his duties as a hero and an asshole, a comic coward and a romantic lead, all with charm, grace, and perfect, perceptive, intelligent, often bold choices in every moment. Cruise isn't a cookie cutter action hero, and this isn't a cookie cutter summer blockbuster. "Edge of Tomorrow" succeeds because of the sheer talent and craft invested, but also because of personality--this sort of movie is surprisingly rare these days, a movie with a sense of personality, a movie with action and humor that's inherently appealing to just about every demographic, rather than the Frankenstein's monsters of watered down, science lab four quadrant assemblies to which we've been privy over the last decade. There's something here for everyone, but, in this case, the appeal arises organically out of the commitment to the material.

It is really unfortunate that this film isn't doing well at the box office.  It's by no means a complete flop, but it really deserved more. (Almost undoubtedly more than the next Transformer film will probably make this weekend.)  Tom Cruise is forced into active duty after trying to blackmail a general, Brendan Gleeson, and in his first battle gets some sort of alien goo spattered all over him before he dies.  This goo gives him the ability to live the previous 24 hours over and over again.  One of the interesting developments of this concept is how Cruise develops from sniveling coward to a human video game; he's done this so many times he now knows where the enemy is going to be before they do.  He gives a great performance.  Always believable and you totally get his emotional state in every scene.  From fear to total bewilderment, to the frustration of no one believing his condition; to his relief at finding a kindred spirit.  His goals also morph from: survive this beach invasion to find the source of the alien's strength and end the war.  His ability to go back in time was previously shared by another soldier, Blunt, and she quickly becomes his partner in training the day before the battle and into the D-Day inspired invasion itself.  
There are a lot of great gags wrought from the "Groundhog Day" scenario, some of the best include Cruise trying to roll under a supply truck and a scrap with one of his fellow soldiers.  You will see Tom Cruise die many times in this film, for many people that will be worth the price of admission alone.  
Of course, this film is not the most original but everything is bent in such an interesting manner that it takes you along without feeling derivative. One aspect I wish was developed more was how Cruise's relationship arch with Blunt's character is a one way street.  He has been with her every day for at least months; every day is the first day she has ever seen him.  This does have emotional resonance in later scenes, but I feel more maybe could have been done here.  
Once Cruise loses his ability the film becomes more of a conventional action fest.  He falls twice from great distances and just slightly limps away.  I felt this was kind of a cheat because earlier in the film these things would have been a "reset."  Also, I was really scratching my head at the final twist at the end.  How did he win again if he was recontaminated reset to two days earlier????  Wouldn't the explosion killing the hive mind not have happened??? Score: 8

After the second iteration of the Normandy battle sequence, I sighed and asked myself whether I was prepared to sit through two more hours of this. The scene is a visual mess, a frenetic blur of exploding sand and smoke and thrashing CG monsters. The rest of the film does tone it down a bit, but there are far too many action sequences for them all to be so hard to follow. It's fatiguing, and few of them seem to achieve any real poetry - they're just blurry. While the two premises are nice enough - perfectly evolved planet conquering space virus and iterative time travel loops - neither of them are executed with any real interest. The aliens themselves, and the "jacket" technology used to fight them didn't do much for me. Cruise is a bland protagonist, which is at least part of why the incessant attempts at humor are so entirely wooden and flat, though the writers deserve most of the blame for that.

Steins;gate and The Man Who Folded Himself developed some really evocative time travel romances, and I think Edge's premise created an opportunity for a fresh version of that premise, in which one partner experiences a year while for the other, every time is the first time. Unfortunately, Emily Blunt, who is a far more interesting character and actor than Cruise, is little more than a tool to forge Cruise into a hero and a reward for achieving it. There were many points when the writers could have foregrounded her, played the whole thing like she was manipulating him to achieve her goal, letting her take the final strike, etc, but she is consistently sidelined. The lack of chemistry between the two, and the paucity of well-written scenes developing their relationship undermines the writers' attempts to play her deaths for pathos. Even the last opportunity to salvage some emotional impact is squandered when the writers employ an unexplained plot device to create a happily ever after ending the story never actually reached.

It wasn't an offensive movie to watch. It is interesting enough in the moment to provide some entertainment value and keep your mind off of its flaws, but I wouldn't recommend anyone waste their time on it when there are so many good movies out there. Watching it feels, more than anything, like playing a videogame, for reasons that are immediately obvious to anyone who has played a video game and knows the premise of the movie. Cruise memorizes map layouts and enemy placements and timings, learns the use of his weapon by repeating the same scenario over and over, there is tepid humor and romance and boring side characters, and obsession with the military, and the plot ends with the protagonists saving the world. It's a bit much.

Or The Best Video Game Movie, Not Based on A Video Game...

I wasn't very excited about the latest Tom Cruise sci fi adventure, since I really didn't enjoy his last sci fi adventure, Oblivion. However, I was very pleasantly surprised about how fun, smart, and inspired Edge of Tomorrow was. It's definitely not the best sci fi action movie I've seen, but there's so much that's good here that it's definitely worth your time. 

Director Doug Liman has effectively channeled the video game experience as you watch Tom Cruise's protagonist relive the same battle over and over again, each time learning new ways to defeat his enemy. It's the closest Hollywood has come to making a really good video game movie, except this film isn't based on a video game. Rather it's based on a Japanese novel titled "All You Need is Kill" (a much more fascinating title), and I can also see the anime influences on this film as well.

Mainly in the character of Rita portrayed by Emily Blunt. Blunt gives a wonderful performance as a strong female character in an action film. She was my favorite character in the film, and I loved watching her train the ill-equipped Cruise character.

Tom Cruise also does something wonderful in this film, he's kind of the opposite of a Tom Cruise character. He's not cool and suave like Maverick or a well-trained warrior like Ethan Hunt or charming like any character he's played in... well anything. William Cage, Cruise's character, is a coward and a wimp, but through Blunt's help he learns how to fight. It was a great turn by Cruise, and I would like to see him riffing on his own personality. 

Edge of Tomorrow does remind audiences how remarkable a presence Cruise is on screen. He's one of the best actors I've seen at taking these big sci fi blockbusters and giving them a human element, simply from his presence on screen. His boyish smile still works and he has a way of delivering lines of dialogue to make them sound more believable and likable. The film benefits greatly from his involvement in it.

There are some definite issues in this film. The supporting cast outside of Blunt and Cruise are rather cartoonish and comical. I understand the idea that they exist primarily to be an anchor for the audience throughout the time travel, so the bigger and wackier they are the more recognizable they are. However, they were just too much for me. Especially in the final act of the film when they are meant to play a more emotionally grounded role.

The final act of the film is also a problem, because it's just too conventional. For a film that relies so heavily on the fact that it isn't your conventional action thriller, it falls into your typical Hollywood ending and that was disappointing. I wanted to see more from this movie, not just what I expected to happen.

In the end, those problems aren't big enough to sink Edge of Tomorrow, and I had a great time in the theater. The one triumph the film has is the fact that it makes me want to see the next Tom Cruise sci fi thriller.

P.S. Watch it in 3D, it's actually worth it.

MY REVIEW OF EDGE OF TOMORROW (3  1/2 Stars)

Here's a fun summer surprise - a big budget, effects-heavy videogame of a movie that doesn't suck.  Oh the many ways this could have gone wrong, but doesn't.  

Featuring a smart, funny script by Christopher McQuarrie (THE USUAL SUSPECTS) and Jez and John-Henry Butterworth (FAIR GAME) and directed by Doug Liman (SWINGERS, MR. AND MRS. SMITH, THE BOURNE IDENTITY), EDGE OF TOMORROW far surpassed my expectations.  It feels like a hybrid of ALIENS, GROUNDHOG DAY and SAVING PRIVATE RYAN, with a little bit of STARSHIP TROOPERS thrown in there for good measure.  

Tom Cruise plays Major Cage, who arrives in London to negotiate his participation in a war against aliens, called Mimics, that have taken over most of Europe.  Unfortunately, he's never seen combat but is forced to join a ragtag squad led by Bill Paxton.  Landing on a beach reminiscent of Normandy in WWII,  he encounters a legendary soldier, Rita (Emily Blunt) but  due to his inexperience, Cruise quickly dies.  This being science fiction, however, he mysteriously wakes up back on the base at Heathrow.  Forced to relive that day over and over, Cruise acquires skills beyond his initial capabilities and joins forces with Blunt to try to annihilate the alien race.  

The filmmakers do a wonderful job with the rhythms of the repetition.  It could have gotten old, but the transitions are smart and swift.  Cruise is a joy to watch as a fearful man in way over his head.  I'd have to go back to WAR OF THE WORLDS to cite of film of his where I rooted for him as much as I did here.   Structured much like a videogame where you learn a little more each time you're killed and come back stronger, EDGE OF TOMORROW is a fun, noisy hero's journey.  

It's fun to see Emily Blunt command the screen as strongly as she does.  Usually more comfortable in comedic roles, her lithe, world-weary character has shades of Ripley from the ALIEN franchise. It's a solid fit.  Besides, her yoga pose, repeated often, is worth the price of admission alone. Because Paxton was in ALIENS, there's no mistaking the references all over his scenes with his troop.  All that's missing is a character named Vasquez.  He works well within the structure of the film, barking out prescient statements at Cruise, meant to make you question the reality of any given situation.  

The Mimics are a fun, original creation with their porcupine-like features and scary scuttling about.  Although I'm not a huge fan of 3-D, the process is most effective whenever one of these aliens pops out at the screen.  Eventually, things become noisy, brash and bloated in the third act (don't they always?) and EDGE OF TOMORROW slightly wears out its welcome, but it's not enough to mar the overall feeling that you've had a time-trippy good time.

You might have seen me in the darkness of the cinema that day, my face lit in profile by the light of the screen, mouth agape, soggy popcorn resting in my gob, eyes wide behind a pair of 3D specks... I was in a state of stunned disbelief. I came to watch yet another rubbish Tom Cruise Sci-Fi action-fest and what I ended up seeing was - nervous cough - a genuinely decent film. It had a great pace. It was sharp. It was funny. It was clever in as much as a Tom Cruise sci-fi actioner can be considered clever. The performances were good, especially the English-rose-turned-blade-wielding bad-ass, Emily Blunt, who is utterly compelling as the so-called "full metal bitch." 
Naturally, once the film had finished, I staggered outside, glancing around for signs of famine or pestilence or even nuclear war... Nothing. It was true after all. I had in fact watched a good film and the apocalypse had not arrived.
On a crucial side note, this alien-bashing cousin of 'Groundhog Day' was directed by 'Bourne Identity' director, Doug Limen and co-written by 'Usual Suspects' screenwriter, Christopher Mc Quarrie. So, with that in mind, it's not such a devastating shock that it came crafted with a certain degree of quality and care. Still, I'll be damned... There's life left in the old Cruiser yet! Fingers crossed for a Top Gun sequel!

It's also an excellent actioner with great wit, strong performances, and a compelling narrative that breaks open narrow but provocative themes (the film subtly adds greater depth to the burden of repeated events and adds a new twist to the trauma of war). *****NO SPOILERS*****

I feel bad for the team that marketed this movie. TERRIBLE trailers!! AWESOME MOVIE!!!

You know when you see a trailer and it doesn't do a good job of selling a movie? That is what happened here in a BIG way, and someone is going to lose their job or will now be apart of the clean up crew at that marketing firm. 

The trailers for Edge of Tomorrow told me that this was going to be a generic science fiction flick, with good stars, who appear to be in a serious ground hogs day action type movie. The worst part is, it apparently did that to a lot of you. The biggest problem (for the marketing team) is that the movie is F#&KTASTIC!!! 

Cage, (Cruise) a high ranking officer who only does PR work, gets thrown into battle and is having this terrible ground hogs day thing going on. That's when the director (Doug Liman) and edit room do an excellent job mixing in the action and humor to take you on this 2 hour sci-fi ride. 

The movie actually gets quite comical, and not the accidental comedy you find in some sci-fi duds. The movie provides you with some real hard laughs, while taking you on Cages journey to make this day go as flawless as possible to succeed on his new mission. Cruise comes into contact with the slightly above average looking Rita (Blunt) on one of his early missions. This sword wielding Rita is definitely The Full Metal Bitch. She is a powerhouse in the war against the aliens and is treated like a Queen by her brethren. This chick is an ultimate badass, and you ask how did she get to be so awesome. Check this movie out, and you will find out why you should start doing yoga!!! lol

The laughter in the movie was great to break up the tension, but this movie also does a great job with intermingling the action and plot. So the excitement is pretty constant, and you don't get any long lulls of dialogue that drag on (like my review) in the 1 hour 53 minute movie. 

I was not looking forward to seeing this film, and found myself all fired up and extremely pleased with it at the end. Edge of Tomorrow was just an extremely well done sci-fi, action, comedy. Great job to everyone involved with the film!!

This movie is just a basket full of summer blockbuster fun and entertainment. If you like action, comedy or science fiction this is a MUST see this summer!

"Edge of Tomorrow" is one of the most surprising movies of the year, turning out to be a supremely fun sci-fi/action/comedy that easily could knock a film off the list of Tom Cruise's top 10 best vehicles (and there are many).  Why do I say the film's success is surprising? I can easily remember sitting in the movie theater, only a month ago, when the trailer flashed across the screen.  As soon as I saw Tom Cruise's face, all I could think was, why does he keep resorting to such dumb action movies for roles?  Based off of his last two movies, "Oblivion" and "Jack Reacher", which have been mildly entertaining but nowhere near the caliber of his past endeavors, it seemed as though "Edge of Tomorrow" would be the final nail in his career coffin.  It wasn't until the hugely positive reviews came out that I actually became fascinated.  Could the film actually be good?
	Surfing on yahoo.com the other day, I noticed an article that called out Cruise's latest choices in projects, begging him to return to pure acting flicks like "Magnolia" and "Jerry Maguire" - apparently, the author had not seen "Edge of Tomorrow" quite yet.  Yes, "Edge of Tomorrow" is a thriller, but it most certainly is not a dumb one.  With the new "Transformers" coming out, along with the sure-to-bomb "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" (both helmed by Michael Bay, who needs to be stopped immediately), it's refreshing to have a popcorn feast that doesn't throw us under the bus.  And considering the only intelligent takes lately have been Marvel superhero films, you can say that "Edge of Tomorrow" is a breath of fresh air.
	Taking place in the near future, where thoroughly evolved aliens are much too close to overthrowing Earth, we find that Cruise has transformed himself into Major William Case, an officer who prefers to give orders rather than go into combat.  His horn is untooted, though, when he inexplicably is pushed into battle by a higher ranking official.  As it turns out, what he is being thrown into is, in actuality, a suicide mission.  Cage dies quickly, but before he meets his demise, the blood of one of the aliens he attempts to kill splatters all over this body.  Why is this detail important? A) The alien he killed is the rarest of his kind and has the ability to reset an entire day and b) this alien is the key to winning the war.
	Cage suddenly is able to relive the same day over and over again, enduring combat and dying repeatedly in the same way Bill Murray showed us back in 1993.  Cage gets lucky, however, when he runs into Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), the Rosie the Riveter of her time - she herself has had the same experience as Cage, and she is able to serve as his counterpart as they travel through space and time to get closer to defeating the enemy.
	"Edge of Tomorrow" is able to be frothy, loads of fun, and durably suspenseful, often all at the same time.  Blunt has said in multiple TV interviews that there were several times where she and director Doug Liman would have a sort of spat in terms of how a scene should be shot, only to remember that neither of them are action movie pros.  But you would never know.
	Cruise performs all of his own stunts, and has done so for years, and throughout his characterization we can feel the fun he is having.  In movies like "Edge of Tomorrow" he is in his comfort zone, and it's a joy to watch an actor who is there for adventure rather than just a paycheck.  His rapport with Blunt is easy going and alive with energy.  She is instantly his most memorable female co-star in recent years.  Minus the one itty bitty kiss they share towards the end of the film, she remains the Hutch to his Starsky, the Crockett to his Tubbs.  Blunt is given the opportunity to be a wise-cracking, tough-as-nails partner a la Black Widow of "The Avengers", and she nails it with a passion.
	Maybe it hasn't made a ton of money in these past few weeks, but for Tom Cruise naysayers, "Edge of Tomorrow" is worth the price of the ticket.  Forget the three hankies you have to bring with you to see "The Fault in Our Stars" - bring along a large popcorn instead for this movie.

'Edge Of Tomorrow' is a sci-fi thriller. In short, it is military science fiction combined with time travel (read time loop) and alien attack! It is based on the book 'All You Need Is Kill' by Hiroshi Sakurazaka.
 
Major William Cage (Tom Cruise), who is kind of a figurehead with no combat experience, is forcibly thrown into a doomed-to-die warfare with an alien race called 'The Mimic'. As expected, soon upon entering the battlefield along with his peers, he faces death. But shockingly, from there itself, he enters into an infinite loop of death and resurrection. 

He realizes that the best way to end this in his favour, is to demolish 'Omega' i.e. the brain of the Mimic. Apart from him, only two other people aware of this death and resurrection phenomenon are - Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt), a Special Force Warrior and her scientist associate. In true blue Tom Cruise style, Cage along with the two aforesaid military people, uses his each new life to further strategize his mind and train his physique, so as to decrease the distance between him and Omega by at least a few steps, before he meets his new death!
 
Like a video game in play, with every death, Cage is required to restart his life from the same time stamp (or level). And like a video gamer, with every new life, though he is required to play the same set of scenarios with pre destined (or planned) succession, he is wiser and better equipped to play the game a tad bit further. So, throughout the movie, he is mostly plotting and preparing for the next day battle, with as many variations as possible. Hence, the movie is titled 'Edge Of Tomorrow' and it's tag line reads 'Live.Die.Repeat'.
 
In the world of movies, this plot is rather new and tricky to handle. Director, screenwriters, cast and other crew members deserve full marks for pulling this off in as much audience friendly manner as possible. A noteworthy scene is the one wherein, just prior to one of her deaths, Rita divulges her middle name to Cage. This scene has a subtle tenderness which is aptly absent throughout the movie. In most parts, the film looks like a gothic mesh of bulky metal combat gear, metallic octopus-like high powered aliens, advanced weaponry and repeat upon repeat!
 
Approximately, twenty years back, Tom Cruise successfully carried off the internationally acclaimed sci-fi thriller, Mission Impossible (1996). And even today, he is carrying such a film with great aplomb. The kind of distinct continuity he has maintained in the film, is no mean feat. Emily Blunt looks extremely athletic and agile. It is impossible to compare this avatar of hers from her stint in 'The Devil Wears Prada'. Herein, she is referred as 'Full Metal Bitch'. But the significance of the same is lost in the book-to-film translation. Others have performed good as well. 

This movie successfully entwines you to the psychology of the protagonist. 
Alongside him, you will experience the same time frame and level of confusion, mirth, determination, fear, boredom and frustration. And just because, it already has so many repeat scenes, it is impossible to see it more than once.

I was skeptical about this movie after watching the trailers. I was excited about another Tom Cruise movie, Oblivion, a couple of years ago. However, it received poor reviews and I never came around to actually watch it. I expected Edge of Tomorrow to be a similar disappointment. However, it received great reviews and praise prior to its release. As such, I cautiously went to see this movie hoping for the best but still keeping my expectations modest. I am happy to say that the Edge of Tomorrow is a brilliant, science-fiction movie and significantly exceeded all my expectations. I left the theater completely satisfied and had no criticisms. It is the best unique concept for a film since Inception. Its idea with time travel, resetting the day, is thought provoking and thoroughly developed during the film. My greatest fear with this concept is that it could get tedious or difficult to follow. However, Director Doug Liman does a flawless job with it. There is no reset that does not add to a great story. In addition, the movie is very smart in utilizing a few funny deaths that provide comic relief. Combined with an alien invasion, the time traveling concept is an unbelievably intriguing story. For a person that loves to study history, I also like that the film features a human invasion of Europe through France to counterattack the aliens. It is a clever acknowledgement of the invasion of the beaches of Normandy during World War II since the movie is released on June 6, 2014, which is exactly 70 years since D-Day. Moreover, Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt provide great performances as the main protagonists, Major William Cage and Sergeant Rita Vrataski. Even after Cruise's recent movie duds, he proves that he can still be a great leading actor in an action film. Blunt is brilliant as the beautiful, bold, and tough "Full Metal Bitch". The two also have great chemistry in the film. While the ending is nothing special and relatively simple, I appreciate that it wraps up a complex story and ties out all the loose ends. More impressively, Director Doug Liman delivers an intricate science fiction plot, compelling human story, good action, and humor in a tidy film of less than two hours. While I would still not classify this film as a must see in the movie theaters, I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a great movie this summer that does not include comic book characters or giant monsters. It is definitely worth watching for all moviegoers so put it on your list of movies to watch even if you do not go to the movie theaters to see it.

Edge of Tomorrow or otherwise known as Live Die Repeat is a science fiction action film starring Tom Cruise, Emily Blunt, Bill Paxon and Jonas Armstrong. It is based it on the Japanese manga All You Need Is Kill. This film was released last summer so there won't be any big awards and achievement yet for this film until next year. Edge of Tomorrow is more of a underrated film due to its risky performance at the box office. Is Edge of Tomorrow a well-received flick or is there a reason why it did badly at the box office? The story follows Major William Cage (Tom Cruise) is force to fight in a battlefield against the alien like creatures known as the Mimics, which they are divided into the Alphas and the Omega. The reason why he is force to fight is because he black mailed the head General (Brendan Gleeson) for sending untrained soldiers into the battlefield. Cage gets killed by the Mimics, but gets stuck into a loop from the Alpha Mimic and wakes up on the day before the big battle. Now Cage has to die a million times in order to be a fully trained solider and defeat the Mimics from ending humanity with the help from a high rank solider Rita Vrataski (Emily Blunt). The plot fells like a combination of other critically acclaimed films like Groundhog Day or the Alien franchise. It brings an unexpected but fun twist at times during the movie like if Cage actually dies the next time if he wakes up or where the Omega Core is actually located like a Damn in London or France. The plot itself is absolutely enjoyable, funny, and unpredictable at time. If I have to pinpoint one problem with the film is the ending. I don't want to spoiler anything about it, it's a bit of a nitpick. This is one of those Science fiction action movies that show that a great story comes with great visuals. Speaking of the visuals, the visuals are the highlight of the movie, especially with the design and moments of the Mimics. I didn't even expect for the aliens in the movie to move so quick that they were on a sugar rush. The scenes when the characters are on the battlefield is the best part to watch since it shows so much visual effect all happening at the same time. The budget on this film was $178 million and I could see why the budget was so big. The battle suit in the film were design as powered exoskeleton suits, similar to James Cameron films like Aliens and Avatar. It looks cool and awesome to get on, but I could see why Cruise character Cage had trouble working it during the first few loops. There's even a hilarious training scene when Vrataski has to trained Cage on controlling the suit better in combat, even if he dies a couple of times. The direction of the film is mostly set in London and France since that's where the film takes place. The director Doug Liam did a great job on setting the film in those areas since the manga was set in Japan. The music in the film isn't that memorable but the sound effect is. The sound effect is more upbeat and big since this was released in theaters that feature surround sounds so big that it kills the THX sound effect in the beginning of a movie. The editing is well done also with a lot of stunt performance done on set. The characters are different compared to the Japanese manga, but are still fun to watch on screen. William Cage was a formal Major who was sent to fight against the Mimics and acquires the ability to repeat time after he gets killed every time on the battlefield. Cruises role in this film is similar to another role that he was in called Oblivion, but its done way better with some of his smart humor he pulls, similar to Bill Murray's performance in Groundhog Day. Then there's Rita Vrataski, a Sergeant who looks hot and smart most of the time during the film, however her character has a short change compared to Cruises character. Dr. Carter (Noah Taylor) is a former government scientist who is also an expert in Mimic biology. General Brigham is just the typical hate able general, who just want to lead the battle his way even if he gets blame for being responsible for all the untrained soldiers dying in combat. There's also the J squad, who are just there as untrained soldiers at first, but actually help the main character out during the third act of the film. It is lead by Master Sergeant Farell (Bill Paxton) who sounds like Tom Hanks at times when he is acting, but still has a few funny moments. If there is one character that I have to pick in the film is the Mimics. Its not there personality that I like about them, it's the way they move around and attack anyone they encounter. They have a dark like color design with little color glowing energy like the orange color is the Omegas and the Alpha is blue. The characters carry fun humor to make the film worth watching. Overall, Edge of Tomorrow is a fun action sci-fi flick with a mind-blowing story, spectacular visuals and enjoyable story. Even though the film is completely different from the manga, it is still a must see film. Also the film is rated PG-13 so viewer desecration is advised. If I have to rate this film, I will give it 4/5 stars or on a scale to 1 to 10, it gets an 8.5/10.

Despite mixed reviews, I enjoyed last year's sci-fi Tom Cruise film Oblivion, as it's nice to see people making new and inventive (if not particularly original) science fiction movies nowadays. It seems as if more and more sci-fi films are either remakes (Total Recall, Robocop), reboots (Prometheus, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes), or sequels (Transformers 4, X-Men: Days of Future Past). This isn't necessarily an awful thing, as remakes, reboots, and sequels all have their place, and can be good in their own right. But if I had to go a year without some new and inventive science fiction, I'd probably lose my mind. 

Thank God for movies like Edge of Tomorrow, a movie that may not be smart on a philosophical level, but is inarguably smartly made. This film gave me hope for both science fiction films and action movies alike, using both old cliches and new ideas to good results. Edge of Tomorrow stars Tom Cruise as William Cage, a poster boy for a war effort against an alien invasion set in the near future. When he is unexpectedly sent to the battlefield, he accidentally gains the alien's power of reversing time when he kills one and is smothered in its blood. Essentially, he now has the video game power of infinite respawn-- Whenever he dies, he comes back to life at his save point. Emily Blunt, who had the power once but lost it, helps guide him on his mission to kill the alien's central control-hive-mind-thingy, and there you have your plot.

What I appreciate most about this film is its willingness to not take itself seriously. Cruise doesn't play his typical character, he instead takes the part of a wimpy, diminutive, whiny little press icon who has never actually seen battle. This is a bit of a stretch for the guy who always seems to get typecast as MAVERICK: The Cocky, Charming Pilot Who Plays By His Own Rules! His performance is one of the strongest ones he's given in years, and he hits every right note when it comes to how a real person would react in his situation. There's also a welcome amount of humor, mostly constructed around Cruise's constant deaths, and the movie doesn't shy away from poking fun at its central premise. In a time when most films are dark, Christopher Nolan-y exposition-fests, I couldn't possibly appreciate this more.

The action is equally strong, and is coherently filmed-- No shaky cam or quick-zooms to be found here. The director and cinematographer clearly understood that action isn't just about physical movements, it's about motivation (a concept that was lost on the creators of Transformers: Age of Extinction). There's a montage halfway through the movie that may just be my favorite action centerpiece of the year. What makes most of this film's gimmicks work are the constant, subtle jabs at the genre itself, and of course the legitimately entertaining action. The semi-futuristic world that this movie crafts is extremely imaginative and involving, from the alien designs to the mech suits worn by the grunts of the military. Altogether, it's a very well put-together film.

Towards the end, the movie starts taking itself a little too seriously, however, and it adapts the darker, explosion-filled style that we all too often expect of modern science fiction films. However, I can't deduct too many points for this, because as the stakes get higher the film clearly needs to have a more emotional climax than the rest of the movie. But did we really need to have a bunch of marines running around in the dark AGAIN? Also, I'm a little miffed at the way the movie uses a plot point that ends up in the vein of Deus ex Machina at the end. It's a little reminiscent of the ending to Source Code, except here it doesn't make any sense (no spoilers!). But since the rest of the movie is so strong, and because I just love movies like this, it didn't detract from my enjoyment much, and I doubt anyone else would say otherwise.

Final Score for Edge of Tomorrow: 7/10 stars. This is nothing more than a simple, fun summer blockbuster, but it really does wonders with its premise. There's a lot to love in this movie, and even if it isn't particularly highbrow entertainment, a lot of work and effort went into crafting it, and boy did it pay off. It's truly refreshing to see an action film that actually took some creativity to make. Take note, Michael Bay. All the makings of a sci-fi classic are here. The characters are relatable, the story is interesting, and the action is actually quite intelligent, unlike Tin Cans In A Blender 4. Altogether an entertaining and awesome experience that people will hopefully talk about for years to come.

I read the book in February and it was crap, so that might've lowered my expectations. Then again, I started seeing all this praise from many reviewers and that got my hopes up, balancing my expectations out. I ended up being indifferent to the final product afterwards, though it's still adequate entertainment and I imagine lots of audience members will accept the film with passion, despite how routine the story feels. To begin with, the movie hints that it will have a strong personality, but it doesn't deliver in the end. Some humour to start off, then this aspect drops off and things become completely flat, the jokes forgotten. I realised my experience was not going to be as good as I initially perceived because during the set-up, none of the characters made an impression on me. Honestly, you don't know anything about them. Does Bill have a family, for example - I have no idea. The same goes for the alien enemies (What's their deal? I don't know). So generally the flaws with the book transferred to the movie. It's a poor screenplay in terms of depth. When you really think about it, everything else tries hard - the screenplay just needed more innovation.

The 'reliving the same day' device isn't original, though it's slightly smart here. Still, it does get tiresome because there are no real jokes and because no new ideas are added to the mix. This is not a mindfuck movie. I was really surprised that it was devoid of frequent twists, or at least one different take on the time travel idea, possibly taking the formula somewhere new. The video game replay idea is the only theme that sustains the movie. It disappointed me greatly. I expected more. I feel out of touch by saying there's not much cool here either in terms of action, music, good guys, bad guys etc. Not terribly troubling to me though - the hollow tone worked for 'Pacific Rim' and 'Ender's Game'. I prefer 'Oblivion', Tom Cruise's previous sci-fi, even though that lacked originality too. In any case, people will adore this 'Groundhog Day' clone because it's passable entertainment. It doesn't do enough, but I could watch it again on disc one day. It has impressive visuals, and I suppose the premise is intelligent. And I just can't dismiss sci-fi. This movie has some fun within, so it delivers to some degree.

In a summer that's all sequels and remakes, "Edge of Tomorrow" is not only a breath of fresh air because it's one of the most original science fiction films in a long time, but it's also very funny, smart and exciting. The plot sounds more complicated than it actually is, so bear with me for a second. Earth is under attack. Alien creatures named Mimics have taken over a significant portion of Europe but after years of being pushed back we've finally been able to hold our ground and are mounting a counter attack. Things are looking up but when Major William Cage (Tom Cruise) is ordered to head into battle by his superiors, he tries to unsuccessfully blackmail his way out of combat, is knocked out and sent on the front lines, despite his lack of training. The attack is a total disaster and Cage, along with the entire front line is dead within minutes. That's when Cage wakes up. Something happened to Cage when he died that first day, and now he relives that attack over and over. Each time he dies, he wakes up that same morning with the army sergeants delightfully informing the people around him that he's a coward and that they're all headed for the mother of all glorious battles against the Mimic. The thing is, Cage retains his memories and is able to change the events of the battle. Stumbling upon Sergeant Rita Vrataski a.k.a. the "Full Metal Bitch" (Emily Blunt) she recognizes what is happening to him and informs Cage that he might be humanity's only hope.

Let me run you by that premise one more time. We have a guy that's got no business on the front line of an alien-human war. He's a coward without any real military experience (it's implied he gained his rank by sitting behind a desk and spearheading the propaganda department), doesn't even know how to operate the high-tech equipment that's given to him and dies within minutes when the attack begins. When he dies, he wakes up again unscathed at the military base where everyone is getting ready for the invasion. He remembers everything that's happened to him so he tries again to go on the beach. He dies again. He wakes up again, only to die one more time. And so on. What's great about this setup is that we have a mix of a comedy and an action movie. As Cage wakes up every day, he quickly gets tired of hearing the drill sergeants yelling the same instructions and motivational speeches all the time. He gets tired of seeing the attack go belly-up and he gets REALLY tired of getting on the beach just to die immediately. There appears to be no limit to the amount of times he can die, so slowly, he begins learning. He starts memorizing where the enemies are going to pop up, what the most efficient way to do everything is, how to avoid people's attention or how to be at the right place at the right time. Every time he lands on that beach he gets a little bit better. Eventually, he is a blur on the battlefield, hitting opponents dead center and being able to instinctively where the next targets are going to be. You see a guy that was a total coward evolves into the ultimate badass on the battlefield... through trial and error. And by trial and error I mean increasing frustration and lethal blows to the head. If you love Tom Cruise, it's going to be awesome because he's charming and gets to become a badass. If you don't like him, you get to see that grin whipped off his face as he gets shot in the head, crushed, blown up, run over and drowned over and over. Eventually he is able to stop people dead in their tracks because he's memorized what they're going to say and everything else there is to know about them. That information helps him get to the bottom of what exactly is going on.

What you won't know about this film based on the trailers is how funny it is. So Cage needs to do something different than just go on the battlefield and shoot these aliens. There's just too many and no matter what he does, he ends up dead. His solution is to look for help, get training and find out everything there is to know about anyone that could help him out. He becomes so good at memorizing patterns and information about people that he is able to infiltrate high-security areas based solely on when this guy bends down to tie his shoe laces, when that girl turns around because she hears the phone ring and how long the elevator door stays open. Unfortunately, it's a long, tedious process that requires him dying every time he gets caught so frankly, the guy gets bored and irritated. He tries elaborate ways to speed up the constant briefings he receives and sometimes, they work. Other times, he ends up getting hit by a car and cursing his bad luck when he wakes up. The best way I can describe the process is by comparing to a video game. If you play a really difficult video game, you will die over and over. You never run out of continues so you keep playing and you start getting better not really because your skills improve, but because eventually you just mentally write down where all the enemies are going to be and what each music cue means. It's the same thing for our hero. Death is no longer something to be feared, it's the ultimate inconvenience because it means he has to go back to the last "save spot" and listen to that boring cut scene again.

I found the movie to be a really inspired blend of an intelligent, clever comedy and a wicked science fiction action flick. The action sequences are tense when director Doug Liman wants you to be worried  and funny when it's time to break that tension with some laughs. As the story moves along, you get to see our main character evolve and become faced with some pretty daunting choices. The recurring side characters are also a lot of fun. Bill Paxton plays a great drill sergeant that revels in delivering his thoroughly rehearsed speeches about the heat of combat and soldiers purging themselves of anything that would hold them back. You can tell this character loves his job an extra percent on the day the movie is playing out because on top of having some fresh meat to break in, he gets to give this particular new recruit an extra hard time because he's a traitor. There are some big laughs between his character, who does not change one bit and Cage, who gets increasingly irritated when every time he wakes up he gets yelled at. Not to be forgotten is Emily Blunt, playing one of the coolest female heroes we've seen in a long time. She's Sergeant Vrataski, The "Full Metal Bitch". It's not enough that she's gunning down the aliens like no one else can, she also wields what looks like a severed helicopter blade as a sword. She and Cage team up against the baddies and it's a dazzling display. They're dodging projectiles and tentacles, doing backflips and crushing the aliens by any means necessary. Their dynamics are really interesting because every time they meet he gets to be a little bit better and learn a little bit more about her, but for Vrataski, it's the first time she's laid eyes on this guy.

The film really fires on all cylinders. The aliens are unique in their design and movements and when it comes to combat, these creatures are so formidable you really realize how stacked the odds are in their favor. The special effects are terrific and look even really impressive in 3-D. There are more than a few scenes where there are tentacles, shrapnel, explosions, bubbles or other things popping out at you and on the big screen with the sound cranked up really high and an audience that's laughing at the funny stuff, it's really terrific. It's a science fiction film that has the perfect mix of admitting it's a crazy story you can't take too seriously and an epic action movie where everything is on the line. Check out "Edge of Tomorrow" and when you do, make sure it's on the biggest screen you can, with a crowd that wants to have a good time and, if you can manage, see it in 3-D too. It's original, funny and thoroughly exciting. (3-D Theatrical version on the big screen, June 13, 2014)

In Edge of Tomorrow, aliens land on Earth and Earth decides to fight back. Cage (Tom Cruise), a lower level military officer, is ordered by his superiors to fight in the battle dubbed Operation Downfall. He is forcibly shipped into battle where he and the rest of the army are defeated and killed, he then has to relive that terrible day over and over and over again. That's right, this film is indeed Groundhogs Day meets Starcraft, and it is endlessly entertaining.

 For the first 40 minutes of the film, Tom Cruise plays a huge coward (you know the word I want to use) who dies many gruesome deaths. Yes, it is huge fun getting to see Tom Cruise dying repeatedly, and I loved that at first his character is so not the typical Tom Cruise we get in films. Emily Browning is also the hottest she has ever been as the hardcore, ass-kicking soldier Rita. She is super impressive here, and I actually dug the relationship between Rita and Cage (It's not really love).  

I saw the film in 3-D and I thought it was some of the best 3-D I have seen in a while. Things are constantly jumping into the theater or into your face, but at the same time we get great depth as well. The whole film is shot in such a way that with 3-D you really do feel like you are there. I love that this isn't cheap science fiction either, it's actually pretty strong stuff.

The director of the film is Doug Liman, who also directed Jumper and The Borne Identity. He actually does a pretty great job here. It also helps that  the script by Christopher McQuarrie, Jezz Butterworth, and Jon-Henry Butterworth is a strong one which has been adapted from a Japanese Manga named All You Need Is Kill (This was the film's original title as well until what I assume was studio interference led them to change it. I honestly still prefer the original title, it sounds more bad-ass). 

In a nutshell: Edge of Tomorrow is what happens when you mix a sci-fi alien invasion film with Groundhogs Day and Call of Duty. I was surprised at how great the result was (especially with Browning and Cruise as the leads).My only real complaint was how they kind of backpedaled on the ending. Edge of Tomorrow truly is an original, innovative, super entertaining , and really funny film that most definitely is worth your time and money. It's the best film I have seen in theaters for a while, and you should definitely see it (in 3-D, if possible).

But I still walked away from this film feeling as if there was so much untapped potential in the plot execution. But for those who do not demand Christopher Nolan's level of physiological indulgence and can deal with Tom Cruise being what he normally is in an action flick, there is still plenty to enjoy here.

Now, despite my rating of this movie I am going to start off by saying that this movie was decent. I don't think it's great, however, I don't think it is the worst film to ever be released. The overall story of the movie is told well enough to keep my attention. So for that reason alone, it's a movie worth seeing at the movie theaters or renting at your local box office; Although it's not worth the twenty dollars for a copy on DVD. Why is it then I gave this movie such a low rating? Even when I said that this movie is worth watching. Well as I was watching this film there came a scene where Tom Cruise talks to a scientist who explains his invention. The scientist explains that his invention hasn't been fully tested. In response says something along the lines of something something something "THEORY". Now why does this word bother me? It's not so much the word as it is the use of the word. Again in the scene a device that is created and hasn't been tested which uses an unknown technology is called a theory. For those of you who do not understand why this would make me cringe, then let me try and explain. In this scenario this device is used as a scientific device which means that it has to go under a little process called the scientific method. This process goes a little something like this. First is the hypothesis, which is just an idea, then the hypothesis is test not just by the original scientist but by other people (a lot of people), once it has been tested over and over again, and has proven to work and is consistent, it then becomes a theory. Which the definition of is "Comprehensive explanation of some aspect of nature that is supported by a vast body of evidence."  (http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=11876&page=11)

So to conclude this review, it is a decent movie but don't go in with high expectations. To conclude my rant, please use the word Theory properly, yes the word theory can be used to mean a hunch, however, when used in a scientific context then it means a hypothesis which as been tested to be true.

This summer has been great for action movies, so can a a veteran action star like Tom Cruise compete? I was a week late to finding out the answer in his sci-fi thriller Edge of Tomorrow but that answer is a very definitive "yes." If you're still sitting around waiting to go see this movie, then I have just one thing to tell you: "On your feet, maggot!"



Edge of Tomorrow is a sci-fi war movie directed by Doug Liman (The Bourne Identity) and stars Tom Cruise as Bill Cage and Emily Blunt as Rita Vretaski. When Cage is asked to head to the front lines, he blackmails his CO, but finds himself on the wrong end of a con and is forced into battle against a vicious invasion by aliens known as "Mimics". The weapon created to fight these Mimics is a battle suit which Cage has not been trained to use. Dropped down in an invasion called "Operation Downfall" on his first day, Cruise stumbles through the battlefield, which is an apparent trap for the human forces, when he comes face-to-face with an Alpha Mimic. Cage takes a claymore mine and plants it between himself and the Alpha, killing them both. But Cage wakes up at the beginning of his day back at the barracks. Despite his best attempts to warn the military of the coming battle, each time he wakes up, he ends up back in the battlefield one way or another. But when he meets Vretaski on the battlefield, who recognizes Cage's condition, advises him to find her when he wakes up. After every death, Cage finds Vretaski who trains Cage in using the combat suit. Together, they concoct a plan to end the war.

Edge of Tomorrow was everything a summer sci-fi movie should be. It was exciting, intriguing, and action packed. The special effects were definitely on par with what we have come to expect from a movie of this magnitude, and at times was even surprising. Doug Liman's direction shines in some of the way he orchestrated the interactions between the characters. This movie is a must-see this summer, which unfortunately is not getting the audience it deserves.

One of the reason this movie is under-performing, although it is successful, is its marketing. The trailers for Edge of Tomorrow were not broadly appealing. After watching the movie, however, I understand why the trailers had to be very vague in their depictions of the film-- if the any of the major plot spoilers had been given to me before hand, I'm not sure if I would have found it as entertaining. One of the biggest surprises for me in Edge of Tomorrow was how funny it was at times. There was never any indication in any preview that this movie would have a sense of humor, but maybe that's even a good thing. I still enjoy going to the movies and being surprised by a movie. Too often lately trailers have been showing us everything and so at the very least I applaud Warner Brothers for keeping this movie's heart and plot close to the chest. 

Overall, this movie stands its ground with the blockbuster kings of the summer of 2014 so far, and it is certainly a must-see. Without hesitation, I give Edge of Tomorrow an A.

Final Grade: A

Liman brings the manga All You Need is Kill to the big screen with Edge of Tomorrow.

 

Humankind finds itself in a World War against an Alien Race. After the war started, major Cage (Cruise) lost his advertising firm and joined the army. He, however, has not seen one day of combat since. As head of media relations it is major Cage's job to sell the war to future soldiers. When Cage is asked to produce an item on the beach of France to show the frontlines, he kindly refuses. That seems not an option and Cage is arrested for dissertation.

When Cage wakes up he finds himself in a training facility near London Heathrow. Even though he tries to explain himself to commanding officers, he is still forced in to battle on the beach. This fight seems to be a suicide mission and Cage ends up dead almost instantly. His death seems to reset the time from the moment he wakes up at the training facility. Cage finds himself in the same battle over and over again. Leaning from the reoccurrence of events, Cage manages to improve himself as a soldier. Together with the Angel of Verdunn, Rita Vrataski (Blunt), he tries to find a way to end this war.

Liman borrows the plot of Edge of Tomorrow from the manga All You Need is Kill. The manga influences are still present in this adaptation of the manga. Rita Vrataski, the heroine, carries a giant sword in to combat as a symbol of her militancy. Instead of the machineguns carried by the other 'simple' soldiers. Limans film also has a strong resemblance with another movie: Groundhog Day. And this is by no means a bad thing. Cruise relives the day as he gets killed time after time resulting in a lot of dark humorous scenes. This also gives an extra dimension to the film. It's not just a hero who tries and succeeds in trying to save the day, he is also learning from trying and failing as well.

Then there is Cruise's character, Cage. Cage is not the type of person we are used to see Cruise playing. The wannabe army major, who has not been in combat for a second in his life is not the determent hero Cruise normally plays. Phrases like "How do I turn the safety off?" while on battlegrounds and the reoccurrence of humorous deaths by for instance rolling under a Humvee make this character an interesting one to watch. The complementation of Cruise's character by Blunt's character Rita plays out nicely. The somewhat strange powers of this weird guy, together with the will and strength of the tough woman.

But this is where the fun ends. The first halve of Edge of Tomorrow is innovatory. There is humor, decent dialogue and character development. The first half borrows all the good things from the manga and Groundhog Day and puts these together in a great storyline. Unfortunately the second half of Edge of Tomorrow lacks these factors. Without this, the attention is drawn to the not so good side-characters and the trial and error that seems to have made major cage in to a real fighting machine. All this is not very convincing.

 

With Edge of Tomorrow Liman produces a decent adaptation of the manga. The dark humor and strong roles from Cruise and Blunt make Edge of Tomorrow an interesting movie to watch. It is however the second half that pulls the final score of this movie a bit down. All in all Edge of Tomorrow is a movie worth watching for both the film enthusiast and the action movie lover.

Luego de ver el trailer, pensé que iba a ser simplemente otra película típica de Tom Cruise, especialmente luego de Oblivion, pero con la cantidad de criticas positivas, decidí darle un chance, y quede sorprendida.
Edge of Tomorrow es una película de ciencia ficción que está inspirada en varias de este género, y a pesar de no ser original, igualmente logra crear algo genial y entretenido. Cage (Tom Cruise) es un oficial que es obligado a entrar a combate, sin tener preparación previa, ya que la tierra está en alerta roja luego de que los aliens se apoderaran de ella. Al llegar a el campo de batalla muere, y pero inmediatamente de eso vuelve a despertar en el mismo lugar en el que se encontraba antes de haber sido enlistado. Luego de pasar por el mismo proceso varias veces, conoce a una mujer llamada Rita (Emily Blunt) que le dice "come find me when you wake up" antes de morir por enésima vez. Al conseguirla, ambos se embarcan en una viaje que tiene como finalidad salvar a la humanidad. 

Esta película fue una gran experiencia cinematográfica, y fue un gran logro haber logrado hacer el método de repetición efectivo, y hasta exprimirle comedia a toda la situación. En ese aspecto al edición fue excepcional, ya que hubiera sido fácil que no fuera exitoso.  Siento que mucha de la resistencia que tiene el público a ver esta película es Tom Cruise, ya que no es ningún secreto que su reputación ha sido afectada por su vida personal, pero no se puede negar que es simplemente una estrella de cine. El esfuerzo que le pone a cada una de sus películas es palpable, y es admirable el hecho de que ya esta en sus 50s y sigue realizando sus propias escenas de acción. Emily Blunt, estuvo genial y creíble como está guerrera, y disfrute de su personaje, porque no es la típica heroína que depende de un hombre para su supervivencia, sino que es una mujer independiente y que toma cargo de la situación.

Recomiendo Edge of Tomorrow, ya que fue una película entretenida ante todo, las escenas de acción fueron impresionantes y los personajes son totalmente creíbles, y una de las mejores cualidades, es que de hecho temes que el héroe vaya a morir. Lo único que tendría que criticar es el final, ya que fue predecible, pero igual no le quita mérito. Esta ha sido una de las sorpresas este año, que ha estado lleno de películas notables de "superhéroes".
